did.unittitle: Levchin, Max, 1975-, Exponential Growth

scopecontent.p: PayPal Co-Founders Peter Thiel and Max Levchin discuss the connections between growth and burn rate during their company's early days. The co-founders also describe why this was a frantic and stressful period for the organization.

did.unittitle: Levchin, Max, 1975-, Coping with Fraud

scopecontent.p: The founders soon realized that a major part of the high burn rate was due to fraud. They admit to being very na├»ve about fraud when they started the company. They had to either find a way to beat fraud or the fraudsters would beat them. They were able to successfully stay ahead of the fraudsters and reduce the fraud rate dramatically.

did.unittitle: Levchin, Max, 1975-, The Initial Public Offering (IPO)

scopecontent.p: Paypal was the first company to file for IPO status after 9/11 and consequently faced much-stricter-than-normal scrutiny. Additionally, the night before a deadline the founders found out that they were being sued for patent infringement. After a sleepless night and rushed meeting with a lawyer, the suit was dropped. The process was so rushed and stressful that it remains just a blur in the memories of the founders.

did.unittitle: Levchin, Max, 1975-, Viral Marketing

scopecontent.p: There is no set formula to make viral marketing successful. Rather, it depends on the situation. It worked with Paypal because customers were able to transfer money to non-customers, therefore growing the network quickly.

did.unittitle: Levchin, Max, 1975-, Changing the Business Model

scopecontent.p: Though Paypal launched the Palm model and the internet model at roughly the same time with roughly the same number of customers, the internet model took off while the Palm side remained stagnant. Consequently, Paypal shifted its company focus toward the internet model.

did.unittitle: Levchin, Max, 1975-, Beating Competitors - and the Conventional Wisdom

dao.title: Beating Competitors - and the Conventional Wisdom

daodesc.p: Beating Competitors - and the Conventional Wisdom

scopecontent.p: The concept of digital cash had been around long before Paypal. Paypal was unique in that it was successfully able to create a compromise between security, privacy and convenience that was acceptable to the customer.

did.unittitle: Levchin, Max, 1975-, Negotiating with eBay

scopecontent.p: The negotiations with eBay were difficult because eBay did not originally recognize Paypal as an essential part of their business model. After a year-and-a-half long negotiation (and a few marketing ploys by Paypal), eBay recognized the Paypal's value and the two companies were able to agree upon the deal terms and valuation figures.

did.unittitle: Levchin, Max, 1975-, Advice to eBay (the acquirer)

scopecontent.p: Peter's advice to eBay for the future of Paypal is to keep scaling the business. At the beginning, it made sense to integrate Paypal's product closely with eBay, but now they are starting to develop applications outside of eBay and these should be vigorously promoted.

did.unittitle: Levchin, Max, 1975-, When and Why to Merge With a Competitor to Dominate a Market

dao.title: When and Why to Merge With a Competitor to Dominate a Market

daodesc.p: When and Why to Merge With a Competitor to Dominate a Market

scopecontent.p: The early merger with the competitor created a unified front that helped convince people that there was a large market with real growth. Though there is no way to tell, it is likely that both companies would have run out of money had they not merged.

did.unittitle: Levchin, Max, 1975-, Paypal is Not a Bank

scopecontent.p: The founders of Paypal are often asked if they are a bank. They are not a bank because they are not involved in fractional lending, nor are they backed by the Federal Reserve. Peter likens Paypal to a money market fund.

did.unittitle: Levchin, Max, 1975-, Looking Ahead to Their Next Venture

dao.title: Looking Ahead to Their Next Venture

daodesc.p: Looking Ahead to Their Next Venture

scopecontent.p: The world is headed in the direction of a global, inter-connected economy in which enormous amounts of money are transferred around the world. Currently, there are outrageous margins on currency exchanges so there is an opportunity in offering transfers at respectable margins.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, Life at Google: Organizational Culture

scopecontent.p: Late one night, a group of excited people congregated in the office of Larry Page, co-founder of Google, over a bottle of champagne. Around 80 people came to watch the event from outside, curious about what was going on. The event was the signing of the AOL contract that was the culmination of months of hard work.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, Science as Inspiration

scopecontent.p: Larry Page, co-founder of Google, reveals that basic research and good ideas are the key components to creating a tremendous opportunity in the tech market. A lot of new knowledge is being created all the time and much of it can be used as the foundation for innovation.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, Innovate in Technology and Business: The Founding of Google

dao.title: Innovate in Technology and Business: The Founding of Google

daodesc.p: Innovate in Technology and Business: The Founding of Google

scopecontent.p: According to Larry Page, co-founder and CEO of Google, not many companies are innovators in both technology and business. In order to be successful in technical innovation, says Page, you must understand the business and marketing side of the equation.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, Tips for the Entrepreneur

scopecontent.p: Google co-founder Larry Page provides several tips for entrepreneurs. Tip 1: Just don't settle. Especially with employees, it is very important to find great people you are compatible with. Tip 2: There is a benefit from being real experts. Experience pays off. Tip 3: Have a healthy disregard for the impossible. Stretch your goals. Tip 4: It is OK to solve a hard problem. Solving hard problems is where you will get the biggest leverage. Tip 5: Don't pay attention to the VC bandwagon. Don't start a company just because you can. Instead, have a really good idea that is good regardless of the funding situation.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, Google History

scopecontent.p: Larry Page and co-founder Sergey Brin started Google while at Stanford working on their PhD's. When the company grew too big to be run from their dorm rooms, the founders made a pitch to a computer science professor who wrote them a $100,000 check on the spot. As of 2002, it is a company of almost 400 people, it handles over 1500 million searches a day, and it has been profitable for over a year.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, Google Culture: Encouraging Innovation

scopecontent.p: Google tries to keep an entertaining and enriching corporate culture by taking company trips and implementing a dog-friendly policy.At the same time, the company tries to maintain an entrepreneurial culture by forming small teams that act like individual startups. The founders have discovered that the groups tend to become more traditional as they grow larger.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, Google Mission

scopecontent.p: Google's mission, according to its founder Larry Page, is to organize the world's information, making it universally accessible and useful. They still believe that search can get a lot better and are working hard to make it so. Google has a global focus and is aiming to do things that matter to everyone around the world.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, Recruiting and Hiring

scopecontent.p: A large amount of time is spent in the hiring process at Google because the company is serious about employing only the very best people. Because of the high profile of the company, they receive over a thousand resumes a day, according to co-founder Larry Page and CEO Eric Schmidt. Many hires result from these resumes, but only after comprehensive reference checks.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, How Does Google Actually Make Money?

dao.title: How Does Google Actually Make Money?

daodesc.p: How Does Google Actually Make Money?

scopecontent.p: Google makes money through selling targeted advertising on its site, which is more effective than broad-based advertising. In addition, they receive revenue from providing search capabilities to other companies, says co-founder Larry Page. Surprisingly, the model used today is remarkably similar to the original business model presented to venture capitalists.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, Partnerships: Google and AOL

scopecontent.p: Google competed with several other companies, including Overture, for the AOL deal. Though Overture offered more money because they are a public company, Google offered more ideas about additional services for AOL customers. The AOL CEO decided to make the decision that was best for the customers and went with Google, recalls co-founder Larry Page.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, What Would You Change to Make Google More Successful?

dao.title: What Would You Change to Make Google More Successful?

daodesc.p: What Would You Change to Make Google More Successful?

scopecontent.p: Everything at Google has turned out perfectly, making it hard to determine which decisions were good and which were bad. Co-founder Larry Page remarks that they could have started the company earlier, but were working on their PhD's. Also, it would have been difficult to achieve the same thing five years ago because the market was not as advanced -- and technology was more expensive and less established.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, Founding Team Dynamics

scopecontent.p: Google co-founders Page and Brin have a unique relationship. The duo share an office, which is said to be one of the most exciting places in the company. The founder-led company dynamic is an important factor in Google's success.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, Success Factors of Potential Partners

scopecontent.p: Eric Schmidt, CEO of Google, talks about how real partnerships are a win-win deal. When making a deal, it is important to let your partner win, too, and to form an actual partnership rather than strictly relying on financial gain.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, Google and Language Translation

scopecontent.p: No matter what language people speak, there is much information that is not in their language. Right now, most of the information available online is in English, but that won't always be the case. Google has been interested in translation, especially as it applies to searching. As of this 2002 lecture, automated translation is not perfect, but co-founder Larry Page reports that they are working to make it better.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, Google's Legal Issues

scopecontent.p: Google has been caught in the middle of free speech vs. censorship issues. The Digital Millennium Copyright Act states that if a company removes information from the internet when requested, they cannot be held liable. If the company is then counter-notified, they can put the information back up and remain legally neutral. Google has followed this policy, says co-founder Larry Page, but it has nevertheless sparked controversy.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, Hiring: What Attributes Do You Look For?

dao.title: Hiring: What Attributes Do You Look For?

daodesc.p: Hiring: What Attributes Do You Look For?

scopecontent.p: The first aspect Google considers when hiring is evaluating the applicant's capability of simply doing the job. Next, they look for people who can think outside the box, but still work within Google culture. Third, communication skills are critical for any employee, even engineers. Overall, co-founder Larry Page and CEO Eric Schmidt have found that if someone is exceptional at something, it is usually a good indicator that they are exceptional at everything.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, Envisioning the Future for Google: Always a Search Engine?

dao.title: Envisioning the Future for Google: Always a Search Engine?

daodesc.p: Envisioning the Future for Google: Always a Search Engine?

scopecontent.p: Google will always be a search engine, despite any additional directions the company may take, because it is a critical part of the mission the founders Page and Brin have defined. Also, says the company, the search engine is far from perfect and still requires many developments before it is complete.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, ROI on Advertising Models Online

scopecontent.p: Google's advertising model has been extremely successful, says CEO Eric Schmidt and co-founder Larry Page. Google has invested in technology to better target ads - and they've found that targeting ads well is in fact comparable to targeting search results.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, Globalization: Google and Asia-Pacific

scopecontent.p: Google increasingly has a global focus; as of 2002, traffic is now around 60% outside of the United States and growing. The search supports 74 languages, including many Asian languages, says CEO Eric Schmidt. There is tremendous growth in Japan, where the majority of portals and online services now use Google.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, Learning to Take Risks: A personal Story

dao.title: Learning to Take Risks: A personal Story

daodesc.p: Learning to Take Risks: A personal Story

scopecontent.p: Looking back, it is easy to forget the tremendous risks co-founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin undertook to get to the place they are today. The co-founders once caused the whole Stanford network to go down for a significant amount of time while trying to develop Google. Page remarks that weird things happen when you are trying to touch every computer on the internet.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, Technology and Social Responsibility

scopecontent.p: The founders of Google, Larry Page and Sergey Brin believe that it is incredibly important for people to have access to information around the world -- and that this is something that Google can deliver. They have run into issues with foreign governments over censorship, but recently it has not been a major problem. CEO Eric Schmidt predicts that Google will become an unintended central focus around global copyright and ownership legal issues.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, Search Engines and Competition

scopecontent.p: In the beginning, co-founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin tried to license Google to other companies because they wanted to finish their PhD's, but none were interested. Google was started out of desperation; they had no other option but to start the company themselves. Though the founders do worry about competition, the barrier to entry is continuously increasing as Google indexes more and more documents and becomes the foundation of so many other services.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, New Leadership and Organizational Change

scopecontent.p: When CEO Eric Schmidt started at Google, his job was largely centered around providing some organizational design. The culture was working well but the company needed more structure. He hired a financial and controller system, instituted staff meetings, and set and reviewed quarterly objectives.

did.unittitle: Schmidt, Eric, 1955 April 27-, Encouraging Creativity

scopecontent.p: Google's main problem is separating the wheat from the chaff through the mounds of creativity they have on hand, says co-founder Larry Page. There are simply more ideas than time and resources allow them to accomplish.

did.unittitle: Huang, Jensen, Branding a Product

scopecontent.p: With every product development, NVIDIA asks What is the purpose of this product and the soul of its existence? NVIDIA has been very successful developing distinctive brand names for their products that describe the soul of the product. These names have become widely recognized and have given the product a personality.

did.unittitle: Huang, Jensen, Where Do We Go From Here?

dao.title: Where Do We Go From Here?

daodesc.p: Where Do We Go From Here?

scopecontent.p: NVIDIA's goal is to light up every pixel in the world. LCD technology has make displays more prevalent. NVIDIA hopes to take advantage of this trend, and future trends, in display technology to drive as many pixels as they can.

did.unittitle: Huang, Jensen, Starting a Company and Fending Off Competition

dao.title: Starting a Company and Fending Off Competition

daodesc.p: Starting a Company and Fending Off Competition

scopecontent.p: If you have a great idea, many other people probably have that idea too. When you start a company, you must assume that similar companies will form to compete with you. Be prepared to fend them off.

did.unittitle: Huang, Jensen, Searching For an Advantage

scopecontent.p: Every company looks for a fundamental advantage, but in reality there are none. Most large markets are designed to foster competition. The question that must be addressed is not how to create one single fundamental advantage for the company but rather ongoing advantages.

did.unittitle: Huang, Jensen, Reinvention and Adaptation

scopecontent.p: There is no such thing as a sustainable great idea. Ideas have to be continuously reinvented. Jensen likes to tease that his company is always thirty days away from going out of business. The world is changing so rapidly that techniques and strategies will be obsolete thirty days from now, and therefore must be continuously changed.

did.unittitle: Huang, Jensen, The Power of Corporate Culture

scopecontent.p: Corporate culture is the single most important thing for a CEO or entrepreneur to focus on in a company today. The culture at NVIDIA is about innovation and intellectual honesty, and the ability to be self-critical and recognize mistakes. Recognizing the power of this culture is very important for a leader.

did.unittitle: Huang, Jensen, The IPO is Not Guaranteed

scopecontent.p: There road is long between the foundation of a company and the IPO. If the IPO is the founder's purpose for starting a company, there is a great probability that the founder will be disappointed. Contrarily, NVIDIA's purpose has been and is to build a sustainable company that can make a difference in the world.

did.unittitle: Huang, Jensen, Fostering Innovation

scopecontent.p: It is important to foster a culture that embraces mistakes and an environment where anyone can have a great idea. The majority of great ideas come out of mistakes and adversity. Adversity should be seen as an opportunity rather than a life-threatening event.

did.unittitle: Huang, Jensen, The Importance of Execution

scopecontent.p: Execution is critically important; it is better to have a simple idea that can be easily implemented rather than a complicated idea that has implementation challenges. Drastic changes do not have to be made overnight; it is a long road to success and each change need only take the company to the next step.

did.unittitle: Huang, Jensen, How a CEO Spends Time

scopecontent.p: Jensen aims to spend his time on what he believes will have a long lasting effect on the company. Numerous meetings and events often take up a CEO's time and it is important to regularly take that time back for product and strategy planning. Communication time with employees is also important -- the most important responsibility of the CEO is being a custodian of the company culture.

did.unittitle: Huang, Jensen, Constant Readjustment vs Long-Term Commitment

scopecontent.p: The company must have a vision and make product choices based on that vision. Once you commit yourself to a product, do not be easily deterred from this decision. Though the product will undergo feature adjustments, the vision should always remains constant.

did.unittitle: Huang, Jensen, Employee Selection Affects Culture

scopecontent.p: NVIDIA Founder Huang, Jensen emphasizes hiring employees is a company choice. With highly skilled engineers everywhere, the choice of who to hire can come down to the personalities and motivations of the candidates. Each employee will become part of a larger team and must mesh with company culture.

did.unittitle: Huang, Jensen, Conveying Vision to Employees

scopecontent.p: The company vision is conveyed through telling a story. Even though Jensen doesn't enjoy public speaking or think of himself as an orator, he understands the importance of speaking to his employees. He emphasizes the importance of forcing yourself to communicate despite not liking it or not being good at it.

did.unittitle: Huang, Jensen, Technologies of the Future

scopecontent.p: Jensen describes 3D technology that he expects will become popular in the near future: lightweight displays that can be worn as goggles allow the user to be immersed in a 3D environment just by looking around.

did.unittitle: Huang, Jensen, NVIDIA's Prospects and the Future of the Industry

dao.title: NVIDIA's Prospects and the Future of the Industry

daodesc.p: NVIDIA's Prospects and the Future of the Industry

scopecontent.p: Business at NVIDIA is going well -- they are selling new products and entering new markets. Though Chinese and Indian companies are threatening their American counterparts, Jensen is enthusiastic about NVIDIA's long-term viability. He does not believe that the industry is particularly scalable; having a thousand engineers is not as important as having the right engineers, and there is an advantage to being in the Silicon Valley where there is a spirit of innovation.

did.unittitle: Huang, Jensen, Positioning NVIDIA as More Than a PC-Based Company

dao.title: Positioning NVIDIA as More Than a PC-Based Company

daodesc.p: Positioning NVIDIA as More Than a PC-Based Company

scopecontent.p: Will NVIDIA have to re-position itself with the slowing of the PC industry? Though NVIDIA is traditionally a PC-based company, in reality the PC-market share is only 40%. However, it is still seen as a PC company and it is important not to re-position the company so drastically that this market will be lost.

did.unittitle: Hershenson, Matt, How the Founders Met

scopecontent.p: All three founders of Danger, Andy Rubio, Joe Britt, and Matt Hershenson, came to the Valley in the late 80's or early 90's where they worked for a series of companies and invariably met and formed relationships with each other. Out of this network, the three men became friends and started Danger in January of 2000.

did.unittitle: Hershenson, Matt, The Founding of Danger

scopecontent.p: The three founders had become bored in their day jobs and were ready to take on something more challenging. Rubio had rented out a little office space in Palo Alto where they converged to collaborate on design work and product development. The idea went through a lot of changes before it became the current product.

did.unittitle: Hershenson, Matt, The Evolution of Danger's Product Concept

dao.title: The Evolution of Danger's Product Concept

daodesc.p: The Evolution of Danger's Product Concept

scopecontent.p: At the beginning, the product was an 'internet sponge' that could absorb information from a computer and be carried around on a keychain. As time went on, the idea went through lots of changes to become what the Hiptop is today. Hershenson describes the formation of the product as a critical mass process: enough stuff (people, money, time) gets scrunched together until the product comes out like a giant release of energy.

did.unittitle: Hershenson, Matt, The Danger Product and Business Model

dao.title: The Danger Product and Business Model

daodesc.p: The Danger Product and Business Model

scopecontent.p: Danger has developed a low-cost combination device that functions as a phone, and is internet and email compatible, that is marketed to the young and hip. The business model is built around the services sold to wireless carriers so they are able to sell the devices cheaply and then make money on the back end.

did.unittitle: Hershenson, Matt, The Evolution of Danger's Product Concept - Part 2

dao.title: The Evolution of Danger's Product Concept - Part 2

daodesc.p: The Evolution of Danger's Product Concept - Part 2

scopecontent.p: The product concept was always to build a low-cost device, but what this meant changed greatly as the founders continued to develop more features. The nature of this device morphed from an internet sponge into the much more complex synergized communicator.

did.unittitle: Hershenson, Matt, Danger's Product Development Process

scopecontent.p: The Danger product encompasses three major pieces of technology: the hardware, the operating system and graphical user interface, and the backend service. The founders drew upon their experiences at Apple and WebTV to know what to develop in-house and what to outsource. Looking back, they are not sure how it all came together and how they got it done, but it was a huge accomplishment when the product shipped.

did.unittitle: Hershenson, Matt, How Danger's First Customer Became a Business Partner

dao.title: How Danger's First Customer Became a Business Partner

daodesc.p: How Danger's First Customer Became a Business Partner

scopecontent.p: Danger's first customer was Voice Stream, which later was acquired by T-Mobile International. Voice Stream was a small company looking for something innovative to differentiate themselves from the competition. They found that innovation in Hiptop. Danger initially treated them as a partner rather than a customer. The two companies provided valuable services to each other and the deal solidified Danger's business plan. Since Hiptop was still in development at the time of the deal, Voice Stream was able to contribute to the product design, including giving it voice capabilities, which was not in the original design.

did.unittitle: Hershenson, Matt, Danger's Business Model

scopecontent.p: Danger's revenue comes from three sources: initial sign up fees, monthly service fees, and through a web share on content and applications that get downloaded to the device.

did.unittitle: Hershenson, Matt, How Danger Turned Down Some Opportunities

dao.title: How Danger Turned Down Some Opportunities

daodesc.p: How Danger Turned Down Some Opportunities

scopecontent.p: Danger decided not to enter the wireless cash market. Hershenson explains the importance of focusing on what is essential to the product, and avoiding nonessential sources of competition.

did.unittitle: Hershenson, Matt, How the Wireless Markets Evolved in US, Europe, and Asia

dao.title: How the Wireless Markets Evolved in US, Europe, and Asia

daodesc.p: How the Wireless Markets Evolved in US, Europe, and Asia

scopecontent.p: Danger was able to break into the US market by convincing wireless carriers to adopt a fixed rate pricing scheme for the device, which is almost essential in the minds of Americans for using services like AIM and web surfing. The Asian and European markets are further ahead and calls are cheaper, making it more difficult for the Hiptop to be profitable.

did.unittitle: Hershenson, Matt, Partnering With Customers Who are Competitors

dao.title: Partnering With Customers Who are Competitors

daodesc.p: Partnering With Customers Who are Competitors

scopecontent.p: Launching the product with T-Mobile helped get the product out on the market and got others interested in the technology, making it easier for Danger to acquire other partners. Still, it was important for Danger not to be seen as a outsource development shop of T-Mobile and so they took steps to maintain control.

did.unittitle: Hershenson, Matt, What To Do When Partners Demand Exclusivity

dao.title: What To Do When Partners Demand Exclusivity

daodesc.p: What To Do When Partners Demand Exclusivity

scopecontent.p: T-Mobile realized early on that it was in their best interest that Danger become as successful as possible. Therefore, they did not demand exclusivity and instead were very reasonable in the contract negotiations.

did.unittitle: Hershenson, Matt, Marketing and the Hiptop Brand

scopecontent.p: The success and genius of the Hiptop brand is arguably in its marketing. Danger actually gave carriers the choice of whether to use the Hiptop name and artwork or whether to use their own. Out of 9 carriers, T-Mobile is the only one to have used their own name and, therefore, the Hiptop brand has become valuable.

did.unittitle: Hershenson, Matt, Designing Products Your Customers' Customers Will Love

dao.title: Designing Products Your Customers' Customers Will Love

daodesc.p: Designing Products Your Customers' Customers Will Love

scopecontent.p: The Hiptop founders designed the product in the way that was the most appealing to them. They had strong convictions about what the product should look like and the things it should do, which were not necessarily the same ideas the carriers had. However, the innovative design won them over.

did.unittitle: Hershenson, Matt, The Value of a VC Who Shares Your Vision

dao.title: The Value of a VC Who Shares Your Vision

daodesc.p: The Value of a VC Who Shares Your Vision

scopecontent.p: The founders acknowledge that they were very lucky in that their first venture investor was from a man who was also a technologist. He understood the vision for the product and was able to assist the founders in solving technical problems, as well as entrepreneurial problems, which proved valuable in the growth of the venture.

did.unittitle: Kawasaki, Guy, 1954-, Make Meaning in Your Company

scopecontent.p: Kawasaki, Guy, founder and Managing Director of Garage Technology Ventures, believes that those companies who set out to make a positive change in the world are the companies that will ultimately be the most successful. He gives examples of the best way to make meaning: increase quality of life, right a wrong, and prevent the end of something good.

did.unittitle: Kawasaki, Guy, 1954-, Don't Write a Mission Statement, Write a Mantra

dao.title: Don't Write a Mission Statement, Write a Mantra

daodesc.p: Don't Write a Mission Statement, Write a Mantra

scopecontent.p: Kawasaki talks about how a mission statement, while touted as necessary for any company, often is not representative of the true meaning of the company. Instead, a mantra is shorter and captures the essence of the organization.

did.unittitle: Kawasaki, Guy, 1954-, Get Up and Get Going!

scopecontent.p: Kawasaki explains that market research, focus groups, and test cases can bog down an entrepreneur and prevent her or him from completing the most necessary task - action! His advice to break the cycle is to think different, polarize people, and find a few soul mates.

did.unittitle: Kawasaki, Guy, 1954-, The New Business Model

scopecontent.p: The business model today is very different than it was before and during the boom, says Kawasaki. In order to write the best business plan possible, follow Kawasaki's steps: specificity, simplicity, and ask women. He believes that woman don't possess the killer gene that is inherent in men, and will be able to give better advice about a business model.

did.unittitle: Kawasaki, Guy, 1954-, Weave a MAT and Outline Your Priorities

dao.title: Weave a MAT and Outline Your Priorities

daodesc.p: Weave a MAT and Outline Your Priorities

scopecontent.p: Kawasaki suggests creating a system of milestones, assumptions and tasks to keep your business on the right path and increase your chances for success.

did.unittitle: Kawasaki, Guy, 1954-, Know Thyself and Niche Thyself

scopecontent.p: Kawasaki talks about marketing and product design simplified. Kawasaki explains why this theory is all an entrepreneur will need to know about marketing. A simple chart illustrates his point - how to be the creator of a unique product or service and is valuable to a customer.

did.unittitle: Kawasaki, Guy, 1954-, Make a Great Pitch

scopecontent.p: Making pitches is a way of life for an entrepreneur. Kawasaki provides his tips for ensuring each pitch is better than the last. His 10/20/30 rule for PowerPoint slides is essential.

did.unittitle: Kawasaki, Guy, 1954-, Who to Hire

scopecontent.p: Kawasaki explains that hiring infected people is the most important factor. Often, how a person looks on paper means nothing if they are not enthusiastic and ready to work hard. All of the experience in the world means nothing if they are not bitten and infected by the start-up bug. He also tells you how to avoid the bozo explosion, which only leads to layoffs, and how to apply the shopping center test to know if you're hiring the right person.

did.unittitle: Kawasaki, Guy, 1954-, Lower the Barriers to Adoption

scopecontent.p: A successful product is easy for everyone to use, immediately. Flatten the learning curve, never ask someone to do something you would not, and recruit evangelists to spread your message.

did.unittitle: Kawasaki, Guy, 1954-, Seed the Clouds and Watch the Sales Grow

dao.title: Seed the Clouds and Watch the Sales Grow

daodesc.p: Seed the Clouds and Watch the Sales Grow

scopecontent.p: There are typical ways to approach sales, but Kawasaki has three other ideas. These include the unintended users, allowing test drives, and the suck down theory - chances are the CEO is not going to be the one buying your product, but rather the people at lower levels.

did.unittitle: Kawasaki, Guy, 1954-, Be a Mensch

scopecontent.p: Kawasaki shares some of the qualities that he believes entrepreneurs, and everyone else, should have. In order to be a mensch, a person who is widely respected and trusted, one should help those who cannot be helpful in return, do the right thing in the right way, and pay back to society.

did.unittitle: Kawasaki, Guy, 1954-, Funding Choices

scopecontent.p: Kawasaki talks about two examples of early-stage funding, bootstrapping and venture capital, and the benefits and drawbacks of both. Ultimately, he believes that too much money is worse than not enough money, and that both methods can be successful of a smart approach is taken with the funds that are received.

did.unittitle: Kawasaki, Guy, 1954-, How Do You Find Evangelists?

scopecontent.p: If a product or services is worthwhile, then evangelists will come to you, says Kawasaki. He believes that if you are having a hard time finding someone to spread the message about your product, then you may need to re-evaluate your product or your goals. Build something great, and the evangelists will be there.

did.unittitle: Kawasaki, Guy, 1954-, How Do You Find Soul Mates?

dao.title: How Do You Find Soul Mates?

daodesc.p: How Do You Find Soul Mates?

scopecontent.p: Kawasaki believes that often soul mates are found within your existing social network, but there is danger in that as well. Close relationships outside of a business environment can lead to promising more than can be delivered. Kawasaki explains that it is a tricky process, and can be difficult if a soul mate is not fulfilling their duties.

did.unittitle: Kawasaki, Guy, 1954-, The Career Path to Becoming a Venture Capitalist or an Entrepreneur

dao.title: The Career Path to Becoming a Venture Capitalist or an Entrepreneur

daodesc.p: The Career Path to Becoming a Venture Capitalist or an Entrepreneur

scopecontent.p: Kawasaki believes there are some lessons one should learn before becoming a venture capitalist or entrepreneur. One thing to avoid is the "Morgan Stanley disease." Investment banking isn't the best way to learn those important lessons -- instead join the sales team of a large company and learn from the bottom up.

did.unittitle: Kawasaki, Guy, 1954-, Experience Is Overrated

scopecontent.p: Kawasaki's viewpoint is not one shared by the majority of venture capitalists. Kawasaki sees the best candidates for a successful start-up are young engineers with no business experience.

did.unittitle: Sutton, Bob, What Is Creativity?

scopecontent.p: Using Play-Doh and the Apple iPod as examples, Robert Sutton, Co-Director of the Center for Work, Technology, and Organization at Stanford University, explains that often creativity is simply making new things out of old ones.

did.unittitle: Sutton, Bob, Two Weird Ideas That Work

scopecontent.p: Sutton illustrates two examples from his book "Weird Ideas that Work." He encourages people to ignore and defy superiors and peers, and suggests trying to learn anything from people who say they have solved the same problems you face.

did.unittitle: Sutton, Bob, Talking About Creativity Isn't Enough!

scopecontent.p: Too often, when companies realize they need to innovate and bring creativity into their company, they spend time discussing it but not implementing it. Sutton talks about some examples of that type of situation.

did.unittitle: Sutton, Bob, Avoiding the Smart Talk Trap

scopecontent.p: Sutton presents three tips for avoiding the common problem that companies face when they talk about creativity but don't implement it, including making sure the people in senior management know the business, and simple ideas are easier to execute.

did.unittitle: Sutton, Bob, Bringing Creativity into an Organization

scopecontent.p: When trying to foster innovation within an organization, Sutton feels that sometimes the best management is no management at all. He also stresses that creativity means selling, not just inventing something.

did.unittitle: Sutton, Bob, Creative Projects on Company Time

scopecontent.p: Some companies like Google allocate a certain amount of time to employees for creative projects outside of daily tasks. Sutton explains how this can work most effectively.

did.unittitle: Sutton, Bob, Questions to Ask a Creative Organization

dao.title: Questions to Ask a Creative Organization

daodesc.p: Questions to Ask a Creative Organization

scopecontent.p: Sutton shares what he believes is the single most important diagnostic question to ask within a creative organization: What happens if there is failure? He also believes that there is no real way to determine which ideas are good and which will fail.

did.unittitle: Sutton, Bob, When Do You Know if You Have a Good Idea?

dao.title: When Do You Know if You Have a Good Idea?

daodesc.p: When Do You Know if You Have a Good Idea?

scopecontent.p: While Sutton doesn't think there is a true method to differentiate a good idea from a bad one, there are ways to help improve the chances of success, the main one being consulting customers or potential customers.

did.unittitle: Sutton, Bob, Research Money in Universities

scopecontent.p: Sutton explains that the majority of research money given to universities does not result in commercially viable products. However, continuing it is often more for the system than the result.

did.unittitle: Adams, Randy, The Early Career of a Serial Entrepreneur

dao.title: The Early Career of a Serial Entrepreneur

daodesc.p: The Early Career of a Serial Entrepreneur

scopecontent.p: Adams, Randy, founder of AuctionDrop, talks about his background, including growing up in Maine, attending MIT, and his realization of his love of creating companies.

did.unittitle: Adams, Randy, The Biggest Competitors of New Ventures

dao.title: The Biggest Competitors of New Ventures

daodesc.p: The Biggest Competitors of New Ventures

scopecontent.p: According to Adams, the biggest competitor of a start-up is a large established company. Their size alone is enough to destroy a young company, says Adams, but large companies are at a disadvantage because they're slow to act and avoid risk at all cost.

did.unittitle: Adams, Randy, You Must Have Vision

scopecontent.p: Adams defines the meaning of vision. He also explains the importance of vision to the success of a company.

did.unittitle: Adams, Randy, Make a Plan

scopecontent.p: Adams talks about how the creation of a plan with a logical set of steps is essential to creating a successful business. Within this plan are attainable milestones and the knowledge that as a small company, flexibility is still an option.

did.unittitle: Adams, Randy, Take Action!

scopecontent.p: Once a plan is established, it is imperative to act on it. As Adams says, most good ideas die for lack of action.

did.unittitle: Adams, Randy, Addicted to Taking Risks

scopecontent.p: Randy has learned from years of starting companies that he has developed an addiction to risk taking. A benefit of young companies is that it is easier to take risks because of the size. There may be nay-sayers, but Randy's advice is to ignore them and continue on with your plan.

did.unittitle: Adams, Randy, Passion and Perseverance

scopecontent.p: Dedication and hard work are essential in making anything successful. Sacrifice may be necessary, and it's important to set priorities, but never lose passion.

did.unittitle: Adams, Randy, Failure is Good

scopecontent.p: Failure is a good thing, says AuctionDrop's Adams, Randy, as it can be a much needed catalyst to make the budding business person strong, humble, and innovative. Think of it as a reset, he says, and something to make one re-evaluate and reset a current course of action. And furthermore, he advises, never, ever quit. Stick around until you get thrown out. And if you get thrown out, compete.

did.unittitle: Adams, Randy, Innovation at Large Companies

scopecontent.p: Will companies like Yahoo and Google become large companies who grow stagnant or will they continue to innovate and remain competitors of young start-ups? Randy answers this questions with examples of company culture.

did.unittitle: Adams, Randy, The Current State of AuctionDrop

scopecontent.p: What keeps Randy up at night with his relatively young company? He states frankly: revenues. Randy discusses a new partnership AuctionDrop has created with UPS Stores, and how they are working to take advantage of the potential within that partnership.

did.unittitle: Adams, Randy, Testing the Market Viability of a New Technology

dao.title: Testing the Market Viability of a New Technology

daodesc.p: Testing the Market Viability of a New Technology

scopecontent.p: Adams talks about testing the viability of a new technology with potential customers. He recommends entrepreneurs conduct polls and surveys to determine whether there is demand for the technology in the market. Never commit to a large development effort without prototyping the technology first and taking it to a potential target market, he cautions.

did.unittitle: Adams, Randy, Work with the Right VC

scopecontent.p: Amidst all of the bad stories circulating about venture capital funding, Randy insists that there are many VCs who are truly interested in the success of a company and will treat entrepreneurs fairly and with respect.

did.unittitle: Adams, Randy, Overcoming the Fear

scopecontent.p: Adams advises that new entrepreneurs ask themselves, what's the worse that can happen? and prepare for it. Hope for the best, but become comfortable with the possibility of failure, he says.

did.unittitle: Adams, Randy, Will Customers Change Their Habits?

scopecontent.p: Using AuctionDrop as an example, Adams explains why it's extremely hard to change consumer development.

did.unittitle: Adams, Randy, Competing with Other Start-ups

scopecontent.p: Adams doesn't worry as much about competition from other start-ups; he views that type of competition as validating the market. It's direct competition from the big companies that is frightening, he says.

did.unittitle: Adams, Randy, Consumer Behavior Changes in Familiar Companies

dao.title: Consumer Behavior Changes in Familiar Companies

daodesc.p: Consumer Behavior Changes in Familiar Companies

scopecontent.p: If consumers are so unwilling to change, why did FedEx gain popularity? Adams asks. He talks about consumer adoption methods and why some things work (internet transactions) and some things didn't (Tablet PC).

did.unittitle: Adams, Randy, Experience vs. Idea

scopecontent.p: Adams answers the question: Will someone with experience and credentials have a better chance of securing a venture finance deal than someone who is new and inexperienced? He believes that a good idea will always prevail. Other factors are important to consider, including team, but the right idea presented to the right VC will win.

did.unittitle: Verma, Vic, Savi Technology Creates the Internet of Things

dao.title: Savi Technology Creates the Internet of Things

daodesc.p: Savi Technology Creates the Internet of Things

scopecontent.p: Savi Technology has been called an overnight success 15 years in the making. Verma, Vic, president and CEO of Savi Technology, talks about what he wanted to do as a Stanford student, the path that led him to Savi, and Savi's various clients and purpose.

did.unittitle: Verma, Vic, Customers Will Say What They Need

dao.title: Customers Will Say What They Need

daodesc.p: Customers Will Say What They Need

scopecontent.p: Verma stresses the importance of listening to customers and learning what they need and want, rather than building a product based on assumptions.

did.unittitle: Verma, Vic, Savi's Winding Road to Success

scopecontent.p: Verma talks about how the initial idea of wanting to track children to cut down on kidnappings and lost children led to Savi's current technology. Along the way, they learned about marketing, R&D, and funding.

did.unittitle: Verma, Vic, Passion and the Customer

scopecontent.p: When listing his first two lessons for aspiring entrepreneurs, Verma says you must love what you're doing, and you must listen to the customer. The customer is always right, he adds.

did.unittitle: Verma, Vic, Flexibility is the Key

scopecontent.p: Verma says that no business plan will stand the test of time without flexibility. Be on the lookout for unintended customers, he says.

did.unittitle: Verma, Vic, Spread the Wealth

scopecontent.p: Verma believes that if entrepreneurs compensate adequately, employee loyalty is sure to follow. He stresses the importance of not being greedy as a CEO.

did.unittitle: Verma, Vic, Hire People for Their Values

scopecontent.p: Verma explains why it is important to hire someone who is hungry, whose values and desires mesh with the company's. Rather than relying solely on the resume, look to these other qualities when building a team, he says.

did.unittitle: Verma, Vic, Dream Big Dreams

scopecontent.p: Verma knows how important it is to have that big dream, and emphasizes that one must hold on to that dream. But it's essential to break that dream up into attainable goals, he adds.

did.unittitle: Verma, Vic, Mistakes Will Happen

scopecontent.p: Verma believes that learning from mistakes is something that every entrepreneur must do, and become comfortable doing. Rather than trying to avoid ever making a mistake, learn from them and move on, he says.

did.unittitle: Verma, Vic, Be Paranoid

scopecontent.p: Verma explains how a hearty dose of paranoia will keep a company fresh. Companies often make the mistake of relaxing once success is achieved -- Verma knows this is the time competitors will strike.

did.unittitle: Verma, Vic, Life Outside of Work

scopecontent.p: Verma warns not to forget about friends and family. A new venture will consume your life, he says, but you must be able to walk away from it when you go home at the end of the day.

did.unittitle: Verma, Vic, Persistence Pays Off

scopecontent.p: Verma says it's not always about being in the right place at the right time, but rather about being there long enough that someone eventually sees you. Don't give up, and pursue it every day, and any dream will become a reality, he adds.

did.unittitle: Verma, Vic, The Reality of Entrepreneurship

scopecontent.p: Verma talks about how it is important to understand the reasoning behind wanting to become an entrepreneur. He stresses that to do it for the money is always the wrong reason. Build something to last, and build it with passion and drive, he says.

did.unittitle: Verma, Vic, Venture Capital vs. Customer Funding

scopecontent.p: Verma explains the different situations in which venture capital might be a better funding option, including the desire to scale quickly. He also points out some of the drawbacks as well.

did.unittitle: Verma, Vic, Sources of Small Business Financing

scopecontent.p: Verma talks about how Savi was approached by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA). DARPA has a small business research innovation program which awards grants to newer companies, and while the money comes with the requisite governmental red tape, it also allows companies to retain ownership of the business.

did.unittitle: Verma, Vic, Know Your Customer

scopecontent.p: Verma talks about how the biggest mistake when identifying a market segment is not identifying the customer with the purchasing power. Your original market can be narrow, and will eventually grow, he says, but only if the correct customers are targeted. Find out who is making the final decisions about a purchase.

did.unittitle: Verma, Vic, Finding Your Strengths

scopecontent.p: Verma talks about his personal transition from engineer to management. He is a strong believer in a technical education, and shies away from general management theories. However, he notes the importance of identifying your strengths, and what you like to do. Everything will fall into place once that happens, he adds.

did.unittitle: Gifford, Hanson, Morgenthaler Ventures

scopecontent.p: Robin Bellas, partner at Morgenthaler Ventures, explains the structure of the venture capital firm.

did.unittitle: Gifford, Hanson, Advances in Medicine: Surgery Without Knives

dao.title: Advances in Medicine: Surgery Without Knives

daodesc.p: Advances in Medicine: Surgery Without Knives

scopecontent.p: Bellas talks about the growing medical trend of surgery without knives and some of the benefits this has.

did.unittitle: Gifford, Hanson, The Foundry: Background

scopecontent.p: Hanson Gifford, president and CEO of The Foundry, talks about why the company was founded and what they do to help fledgling companies get off the ground and become successful. The incubation process that The Foundry goes through with each new venture helps these companies increase their chances of receiving funding, he says.

did.unittitle: Gifford, Hanson, Why Does The Foundry Work as an Incubator?

dao.title: Why Does The Foundry Work as an Incubator?

daodesc.p: Why Does The Foundry Work as an Incubator?

scopecontent.p: Gifford has found that having The Foundry act as an incubator was the best method possible to help new ventures get started. Over the cycles of incubation, The Foundry becomes familiar with procedures such as the FDA approval process and clinical trial details.

did.unittitle: Gifford, Hanson, Choosing the Right Medical Devices to Fund

dao.title: Choosing the Right Medical Devices to Fund

daodesc.p: Choosing the Right Medical Devices to Fund

scopecontent.p: The Foundry can only fund a certain number of ventures. Hanson talks about the different factors that go into choosing the companies, including market opportunity, and patient and physician opportunity.

did.unittitle: Gifford, Hanson, The Unique Relationship Between Morgenthaler and The Foundry

dao.title: The Unique Relationship Between Morgenthaler and The Foundry

daodesc.p: The Unique Relationship Between Morgenthaler and The Foundry

scopecontent.p: While Morgenthaler funds The Foundry, they are also, in essence, funding each new venture that The Foundry incubates. Bellas and Gifford describe the details of this relationship, including the reasons behind establishing it and how they successfully maintain it.

did.unittitle: Gifford, Hanson, Where Does Innovation Occur?

scopecontent.p: Bellas talks about where innovation is currently happening in biotech and medical device companies. The large pharmaceutical companies aren't covering the same innovative ground as the smaller companies, which is a trend seeing in every tech field.

did.unittitle: Gifford, Hanson, Insight Into the Changing Valuations of Companies Since the Dot Com Era

dao.title: Insight Into the Changing Valuations of Companies Since the Dot Com Era

daodesc.p: Insight Into the Changing Valuations of Companies Since the Dot Com Era

scopecontent.p: The dot com bubble has changed the way companies are now valued, and their valuations over time. Bellas discusses how valuations are currently determined, and typical financing and return amounts.

did.unittitle: Gifford, Hanson, Examples of Groundbreaking Achievements in Medicine (Part 1)

dao.title: Examples of Groundbreaking Achievements in Medicine (Part 1)

daodesc.p: Examples of Groundbreaking Achievements in Medicine (Part 1)

scopecontent.p: Bellas talks about two Foundry companies which utilize new surgical procedures. The first is Thermage, which uses a procedure that stimulates new collagen growth. The second is Xstent, which works with stent implants.

did.unittitle: Gifford, Hanson, Examples of Groundbreaking Achievements in Medicine (Part 2)

dao.title: Examples of Groundbreaking Achievements in Medicine (Part 2)

daodesc.p: Examples of Groundbreaking Achievements in Medicine (Part 2)

scopecontent.p: Gifford discusses some Foundry companies that are showing great success rates, including: Concentric, which treats acute ischemic strokes; Emphasis, with a procedure replacing open-heart surgery with an outpatient procedure, First to File, a non-medical project focusing on intellectual property management; and Satiety, which treats morbid obesity.

did.unittitle: Fodor, Steve, Intellectual Property and Life Sciences

scopecontent.p: Fodor, Steve, co-founder of Affymetrix, talks about the importance of continuing the scientific research within a company despite a perceived monopoly of the field. The most important thing is not intellectual property, but development of good products.

did.unittitle: Fodor, Steve, Which Came First, the Market or the Technology?

dao.title: Which Came First, the Market or the Technology?

daodesc.p: Which Came First, the Market or the Technology?

scopecontent.p: Fodor understands the dilemma of creating technology for a non-existent market. However, he has seen over the years that as the technology has evolved, the market begin to revolve around it. His key to success? Staying in front of it at all times.

did.unittitle: Fodor, Steve, The Scientist vs. the Entrepreneur

scopecontent.p: At the heart of scientific research is innovation, says Fodor, which is also one of the main driving forces behind entrepreneurship. He talks about making the transition from scientist to entrepreneur.

did.unittitle: Richardson, Karen, A Girl Among Geeks

scopecontent.p: Richardson, Karen, CEO of E.piphany, talks briefly about her family background, and the attitude any entrepreneur should adopt.

did.unittitle: Richardson, Karen, What E.piphany Does

scopecontent.p: Richardson provides a short description of E.piphany's background and business model.

did.unittitle: Richardson, Karen, The 20th Century Gold Rush

scopecontent.p: Richardson describes the mood in Silicon Valley during the 1990's when companies were hurrying to grow and go public.

did.unittitle: Richardson, Karen, To Stay Private or Go Public

dao.title: To Stay Private or Go Public

daodesc.p: To Stay Private or Go Public

scopecontent.p: An entrepreneur with a successful venture may be faced with the choice of keeping the company private or moving ahead with an IPO. Richardson talks about the preliminary stage in that particular decision making process.

did.unittitle: Richardson, Karen, What Kind of Person Are You?

dao.title: What Kind of Person Are You?

daodesc.p: What Kind of Person Are You?

scopecontent.p: Richardson talks about how asking if you are a private or public person may help in determining the path your company should take. She outlines pros and cons for both options.

did.unittitle: Richardson, Karen, The Cost of Doing Business

scopecontent.p: Richardson talks about how a major factor when deciding whether or not to go public is the cost. Sarbanes-Oxley has affected the cost for public companies significantly.

did.unittitle: Richardson, Karen, The Sarbanes-Oxley Act

scopecontent.p: Richardson explains the rigorous reporting expectations created by the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, and their effect on a company.

did.unittitle: Richardson, Karen, Public vs. Private Pros and Cons

dao.title: Public vs. Private Pros and Cons

daodesc.p: Public vs. Private Pros and Cons

scopecontent.p: Richardson reviews the pros and cons of going public versus staying private. She gives an example of a successful private company, as well as a few well-known public companies.

did.unittitle: Richardson, Karen, Company Ethics

scopecontent.p: Richardson talks about how prior to the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, unethical behavior in companies was considered standard practice. She explains ways in which to stop those practices and maintain a level of ethics within a company.

did.unittitle: Richardson, Karen, A Member of the CEO Minority

dao.title: A Member of the CEO Minority

daodesc.p: A Member of the CEO Minority

scopecontent.p: Richardson discusses what it is like to be one of only a handful of female top execs of large companies in the U.S.

did.unittitle: Richardson, Karen, Lessons from Failure

scopecontent.p: At various points in her career, Richardson has been part of companies that have failed. She talks about the lessons she learned from those failures and how they have shaped her career.

did.unittitle: Doerr, John E., Distinguished Ventures

scopecontent.p: Doerr, John, partner at Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, talks about what distinguishes successful companies from all others. The two main factors are passionate founders and devotion to technical excellence.

did.unittitle: Doerr, John E., Mercenaries and Missionaries

scopecontent.p: Doerr views entrepreneurs as missionaries rather than mercenaries, and gives examples of both groups, including drive and paranoia (mercenary) and passion (missionary).

did.unittitle: Doerr, John E., Great Groups

scopecontent.p: Doerr firmly believes that one of the keys to success is a strong partnership, rather than a lone entrepreneur forging ahead.

did.unittitle: Doerr, John E., Helping Teams Work Together

scopecontent.p: Doerr offers tips that are useful in building a strong team and sustaining its strength, including coaching and personal networking.

did.unittitle: Doerr, John E., Disruptive Technologies

scopecontent.p: Doerr gives his list of what he feels are important new disruptive technologies. His first choice is wireless and his second is services for enterprises.

did.unittitle: Doerr, John E., The Past, Present and Future of Google

dao.title: The Past, Present and Future of Google

daodesc.p: The Past, Present and Future of Google

scopecontent.p: As a well-known champion of Google, Doerr describes some of his favorite services that Google offers.

did.unittitle: Doerr, John E., The Impact of Social Entrepreneurship

scopecontent.p: Doerr talks about how Grameen Bank, started by Professor Muhammad Yunus, proved to be a creative solution to the never-ending problem of poverty for many small villages in Bangladesh. Doerr shares the story of finding this solution and the ideas behind how the bank came to be formed.

did.unittitle: Doerr, John E., Career Advice

scopecontent.p: Doerr gives general career advice for those who are planning to start their own businesses. His tips include finding a mentor, networking, and spending some time in a sales or service position.

did.unittitle: Doerr, John E., How To Be a Venture Capitalist

dao.title: How To Be a Venture Capitalist

daodesc.p: How To Be a Venture Capitalist

scopecontent.p: Doerr talks about how many students on the eve of graduation set their sights on becoming a venture capitalist. He believes the path to being a great venture capitalist begins with being a great entrepreneur.

did.unittitle: Doerr, John E., The Global Future

scopecontent.p: When asked what the future of technology and venture capital will look like, Doerr frames it as career advice for his daughters: learn Mandarin and earn a degree in a biotechnology related field.

did.unittitle: Doerr, John E., How to Negotiate Valuations

scopecontent.p: Doerr offers advice on pursuing initial VC funding, including how many firms to approach, how to evaluate the firms, and what kinds of questions to ask. He also reminds us to treat all negotiations with respect and fairness.

did.unittitle: Fleury, Marc, The Dynamics of Open Source Software

dao.title: The Dynamics of Open Source Software

daodesc.p: The Dynamics of Open Source Software

scopecontent.p: Peter Fenton, general partner at Benchmark Capital, discusses what the future may look like with open source software, and how competitors view open source software companies.

did.unittitle: Fenton, Peter , The Relationship Between Venture Capital and Open Source

dao.title: The Relationship Between Venture Capital and Open Source

daodesc.p: The Relationship Between Venture Capital and Open Source

scopecontent.p: The logic behind backing a company that does not charge anything for their product is sometimes hard to understand. Fenton explains the unique relationships between a venture capital firm and an open source company they fund.

did.unittitle: Fleury, Marc, Balancing Science and Business

scopecontent.p: Fleury, Marc, creator of JBoss, explains why it is important, for those in business with an engineering background, to not abandon the science but embrace it. Striking a balance between the two will make for a more successful entrepreneur.

did.unittitle: Fleury, Marc, What Can a VC Do For You?

dao.title: What Can a VC Do For You?

daodesc.p: What Can a VC Do For You?

scopecontent.p: Fleury talks about how along with financial backing, VC's have a unique body of knowledge that is highly useful for anyone starting their own business.

did.unittitle: Fleury, Marc, The Importance of Establishing Critical Mass

dao.title: The Importance of Establishing Critical Mass

daodesc.p: The Importance of Establishing Critical Mass

scopecontent.p: Fleury talks about establishing and maintaining a critical mass within the market. Without it, he explains, you will find yourself in a very difficult situation and VCs will view you differently.

did.unittitle: Fleury, Marc, The Benefit of Picking the Right VC

dao.title: The Benefit of Picking the Right VC

daodesc.p: The Benefit of Picking the Right VC

scopecontent.p: Fleury believes the relationship between VC and entrepreneur is very important. Therefore, it is essential to pick the right VC, he says. He offers a few pointers on how to find the VC that is right for you.

did.unittitle: Ku, Katharine, What's Best for the Technology?

scopecontent.p: Katherine Ku, Director of the Office of Technology Licensing (OTL) at Stanford University, talks about the mission of the OTL at Stanford. Their main philosophy is to do what's best for the technology, and that doesn't always mean going for the top dollar.

did.unittitle: Ku, Katharine, Maintaining Good Relationships

scopecontent.p: Ku believes technology licensing is not always about licensing products and making money. It's also about fostering lasting relationships with companies and individuals. She talks about some of the interactions and relationships that Stanford University has with outside groups.

did.unittitle: Ku, Katharine, The Licensing Process

scopecontent.p: Ku describes the process of licensing a technology from start to finish.

did.unittitle: Ku, Katharine, The Big Ones

scopecontent.p: Ku talks about some of the big licenses to come out of Stanford University since the beginning of the Office of Technology Licensing.

did.unittitle: Ku, Katharine, The Sobering Truth About Technology Licensing

dao.title: The Sobering Truth About Technology Licensing

daodesc.p: The Sobering Truth About Technology Licensing

scopecontent.p: Most people might assume that Stanford University generates a large number of high profit licenses. Ku explains what the financial numbers really look like on average.

did.unittitle: Ku, Katharine, Royalties and Patents

scopecontent.p: Ku talks about what the Office of Technology Licensing is really looking for in terms of what will be a successful patent.

did.unittitle: Ku, Katharine, Entrepreneurs in a University

scopecontent.p: More and more universities are starting to see faculty and students create start ups. However, sometimes a conflict of interest can arise. Ku discusses how her office handles these entrepreneurs and conflicts.

did.unittitle: Ku, Katharine, A Career in Technology Licensing

scopecontent.p: Ku talks about how the main appeal of a career in technology licensing is that it is never the same position from one day to the next. There is the opportunity to meet new people, create an astounding network, and to always know what is on the cutting edge of research and technology.

did.unittitle: Ku, Katharine, Licensing Success Rate

scopecontent.p: Simply having a new technology is not enough to gain a license. Ku talks about how the Office of Technology Licensing at Stanford asseses each technology, and what recommendations they might make to the entrepreneur.

did.unittitle: Ku, Katharine, Cross-licensing and International Patents

scopecontent.p: Ku discusses the expense of international patents and how they tend to approach international markets.

did.unittitle: Ku, Katharine, The Bayh-Dole Act

scopecontent.p: Ku explains the impact of the Bayh-Dole Act on international and domestic technology licensing.

did.unittitle: Ku, Katharine, How Much is the Technology Worth?

dao.title: How Much is the Technology Worth?

daodesc.p: How Much is the Technology Worth?

scopecontent.p: As Ku says, pricing a technology is an art, not a science. She describes the process of determining the equity volume of the various technologies that her office sees.

did.unittitle: Byers, Brook, VC Industry: An Ecosystem

scopecontent.p: Byers, Brook, partner at KPCB, talks about the diversity of the VC industry and uses a biological metaphor to compare the industry to an ecosystem.

did.unittitle: Byers, Brook, Evolution of Start-up Companies

scopecontent.p: Byers talks about the trends in which startups evolved from the mid 90's to the late 90's.

did.unittitle: Byers, Brook, Size of VC Firms

scopecontent.p: Byers discusses the different ways in which venture capital firms size themselves and makes recommendations on how they should go about investing.

did.unittitle: Byers, Brook, Magic Mondays

scopecontent.p: Magic Monday is a meeting day for venture capitalists. Byers talks about the importance of Mondays in venture capitalist organizations.

did.unittitle: Byers, Brook, Decision-Making at Kleiner Perkins

scopecontent.p: Byers gives an insight into the decision-making process at Kleiner Perkins on how it makes investment decisions. He advises entrepreneurs on ways to champion starting a selling process in the firm.

did.unittitle: Byers, Brook, Knowing Your Customers

scopecontent.p: Byers believes that entrepreneurs should have a strong resonance with their customers. An acid test for entrepreneurs is to know their audience.

did.unittitle: Byers, Brook, Getting Funding

scopecontent.p: Byers discusses the process and the time that it takes for an entrepreneur to earn a standing to the time when he might get financed.

did.unittitle: Byers, Brook, Multiple Investors

scopecontent.p: Byers believes that two to three co-investors is a good set for a young venture. An entrepreneur should balance between the number of investors and their minimum stake in the company.

did.unittitle: Byers, Brook, Looking for Investors

scopecontent.p: Byers discusses the number of co-investors one should approach and suggests that while going to investors one should know about their investors very well.

did.unittitle: Byers, Brook, The Ideal Team

scopecontent.p: What does Kleiner Perkins perceive to be an ideal team? Byers believes that an ideal team simply comprises of just the essential people.

did.unittitle: Byers, Brook, Developing Close Working Relationships

scopecontent.p: Byers reveals how Kleiner Perkins develops close working relationships with its teams by following the 'We are all in this together' attitude.

did.unittitle: Byers, Brook, Passion for Work

scopecontent.p: Byers' passion for his work is the driving force behind his success.

did.unittitle: Byers, Brook, Importance of Stem Cell

scopecontent.p: Byers talks about how he got involved in the stem cell initiative and its importance to him.

did.unittitle: Byers, Brook, Career Advice

scopecontent.p: Byers advices graduating students who are budding entrepreneurs to look for a company that will mentor and train them with invaluable experience.

did.unittitle: Denman, Kenneth, Importance of a Scalable Business Model and Architecture

dao.title: Importance of a Scalable Business Model and Architecture

daodesc.p: Importance of a Scalable Business Model and Architecture

scopecontent.p: Denman, Kenneth, chairman, president and chief executive officer of iPass, believes that the architecture of a new business will make or break an entrepreneur. He discusses the importance of a scalable business model and the difference in the vision of the smaller companies versus the bigger companies.

did.unittitle: Denman, Kenneth, Creating Value in a Growing Business

dao.title: Creating Value in a Growing Business

daodesc.p: Creating Value in a Growing Business

scopecontent.p: Denman talks about how market experience, periodic reinvention through increase in capacity as well as capturing capital create significant value to a growing business.

did.unittitle: Moore, Geoffrey, Innovation Crisis at Established Enterprises

scopecontent.p: Moore, Geoffrey, best selling author and a Managing Director at TCG Advisors, talks about how inertia overrides innovation in established enterprises.

did.unittitle: Moore, Geoffrey, Innovation and Inertia

scopecontent.p: Moore advises that since innovation begets inertia, there is a need for companies to recycle their resources with respect to both innovation and inertia to differentiate themselves in a competitively driven market.

did.unittitle: Moore, Geoffrey, Market Maturity Life Cycle

scopecontent.p: Moore focuses on innovation and discusses the different stages in the market maturity life cycle.

did.unittitle: Moore, Geoffrey, Innovation Zones

scopecontent.p: Moore elaborates on the four different innovation zones: product leadership, operational excellence, customer intimacy and value renewal. These zones make up the market maturity life cycle.

did.unittitle: Moore, Geoffrey, Classes of Innovations in the Product Leadership Zone

dao.title: Classes of Innovations in the Product Leadership Zone

daodesc.p: Classes of Innovations in the Product Leadership Zone

scopecontent.p: Moore looks at the different classes of innovation that comprise the product leadership zone: disruptive, application, product and platform innovation. These innovation zones are driven by the technology adoption life cycle and are very R&D intensive and high-risk.

did.unittitle: Moore, Geoffrey, Fractal Markets

scopecontent.p: Moore explains the concept of fractalization of markets when markets get out of the growth phase.

did.unittitle: Moore, Geoffrey, Customer Intimacy Zone

scopecontent.p: Moore delves into the "customer intimacy zone" to explain the innovations that comprise this zone: line extension, enhancement, marketing,and experiential innovations

did.unittitle: Moore, Geoffrey, Operational Excellence Zone

scopecontent.p: Moore talks about the operational excellence zone and its innovations: value engineering, process, integration and business model innovation.

did.unittitle: Moore, Geoffrey, McKinsey's 7S's Model

scopecontent.p: Moore uses McKinsey's 7S's model to attack the problem of inertia in companies.

did.unittitle: Moore, Geoffrey, Core and Context

scopecontent.p: Moore uses the core/context analysis framework to discuss how to overcome inertia in strategy and structure.

did.unittitle: Moore, Geoffrey, Inertia: Residue of Innovation

scopecontent.p: Moore believes inertia is the legacy of successful innovation and the two must be managed as a single system in a business enterprise.

did.unittitle: Seligmann, Peter, Birth of Conservation International

scopecontent.p: Seligmann, Peter, co-founder, chairman and CEO of Conservation International, talks about how he got interested in forestry. He discusses how Conservation International got started and the company's motto.

did.unittitle: Seligmann, Peter, Importance of Science in Conservation

scopecontent.p: Seligmann strongly believes that it is the science that is constantly assessing the ecological health of the system.

did.unittitle: Seligmann, Peter, China: Future of Global Environment

scopecontent.p: Seligmann, Peter, CEO of Conservation International, believes that China is the future of global environment, a country leading the world on how to preserve its natural ecosystems. He emphasizes that once the relationship between wealth, health and environment is realized by society, people will begin to understand that long-term survival is going to depend upon the availability of resources.

did.unittitle: Seligmann, Peter, Debt-for-Nature

scopecontent.p: Seligmann explains the concept of debt-for-nature that is used by many organizations like World Wildlife Fund and Nature Conservancy to make deals all around the world: exchanging debt and converting it into currency.

did.unittitle: Seligmann, Peter, Achieving Resource Sustainability

scopecontent.p: Seligmann affirms that there are many business leaders interested in sustainability who understand the importance of sustainability for resource-related businesses.

did.unittitle: Seligmann, Peter, Establishing Credibility

scopecontent.p: Seligmann talks about how a not-for-profit organization like Conservation International builds its credibility when interacting with governments of other countries.

did.unittitle: Dunn, Debra, Leadership and Change Management

scopecontent.p: Debra Dunn, former vice president of strategy and corporate operations at Hewlett Packard, and Komisar, Randy, partner at Kleiner Perkins Caufield and Byers, believe that leadership skills and the ability to handle change comfortably are the key characteristics that have been useful in their respective careers.

did.unittitle: Dunn, Debra, Growing with Hewlett Packard

scopecontent.p: Dunn discusses her foray into the business world and why she decided to work at Hewlett Packard. She describes how the values of the company strongly resonate with her and the company has provided her with many opportunitites.

did.unittitle: Dunn, Debra, Getting into Kleiner Perkins

scopecontent.p: Komisar talks about his transition from teaching at Stanford to getting into the structured environment of venture capital firms. He discusses the things he found appealing about his job as a partner at Kleiner Perkins Caufield and Byers.

did.unittitle: Dunn, Debra, Skills for Social Entrepreneurship

scopecontent.p: Dunn talks about how the skills that she has acquired in a traditional company like Hewlett Packard will be useful in solving social problems in non-profit ventures.

did.unittitle: Dunn, Debra, Traditional Companies making Social Differences

scopecontent.p: Komisar talks about how many traditional companies like Kleiner Perkins are involved in making significant social differences. He believes that the entreprenuerial spirit and pursuit of innovation of these companies is consistent to the model of many social ventures in the market.

did.unittitle: Dunn, Debra, Creativity versus Control

scopecontent.p: Dunn and Komisar share their philosophies about how much to plan one's careers versus creating and taking opportunities as they present themselves.

did.unittitle: Dunn, Debra, Career Advice

scopecontent.p: Dunn and Komisar give advice to graduating students from Stanford University to never stop learning as well as spend a considerable amount of time to figure out the things one is truly passionate about.

did.unittitle: Dunn, Debra, Lack of Business Rigor in the Non-Profit World

dao.title: Lack of Business Rigor in the Non-Profit World

daodesc.p: Lack of Business Rigor in the Non-Profit World

scopecontent.p: Dunn believes that lack of transparency has led to a lack of competition in the non-profit world, which has witnessed an absence of business rigor. She is confident that there is an opportunity for radical transformation in the non-profit world.

did.unittitle: Dunn, Debra, Success in Venture Capital Firms

scopecontent.p: Komisar believes that the ability and commitment to building businesses rather than just investing in it is what makes successful venture capital firms.

did.unittitle: McNamee, Roger, Successful Entrepreneurs

scopecontent.p: McNamee, Roger, Managing Director and Co-Founder of Elevation Partners, believes that successful entrepreneurs are driven by compelling ideas. He goes on to say that along with great ideas, skills, personality and the determination to execute them, having a plan greatly increases one's chances of success.

did.unittitle: McNamee, Roger, Self-Awareness

scopecontent.p: McNamee advises that it is important for entrepreneuers to patiently assess what one is good/bad at doing and what are the right opprtunities. The time spent on this self-awareness process is crucial to getting things right in a business, he says.

did.unittitle: McNamee, Roger, Family is Part of Your Startup

dao.title: Family is Part of Your Startup

daodesc.p: Family is Part of Your Startup

scopecontent.p: When McNamee says, 'Your most important partner in a business is your spouse,' he believes that when working in a partnership, partners assimilate each other's passions, issues, and interests. He also says that life is all about balancing one's career, family and bank account and all three are necessary for entrepreneurship.

did.unittitle: Draper, Tim, Who are Entrepreneurs?

scopecontent.p: Draper, Tim, Founder and co-Managing Director of Draper Fisher Jurvetson, compares entrepreneurs to 'heroes and heroines' who are willing to take huge risks to work for an extraordinary outcome.

did.unittitle: Draper, Tim, The DFJ Network

scopecontent.p: Draper discusses why the DFJ Network was formed. The DFJ Network is looking for 'heroes' with passion and energy to lead a business to change the way the world works.

did.unittitle: Draper, Tim, Moore's Law

scopecontent.p: Draper applies Moore's law to all science as it is growing exponentially and spreading very quickly.

did.unittitle: Hawkins, Jeff, What is Entrepreneurship?

scopecontent.p: Hawkins, Jeff, co-founder of Palm Computing, talks about what entrepreneurship is and isn't. Hawkins views entrepreneurship as a tool that is to be used sparingly and as a last resort. It is a tool to be used to pursue or accomplish one's goal in life, he says.

did.unittitle: Hawkins, Jeff, Following Your Goal

scopecontent.p: Hawkins advises everyone to find their passion and to use the fastest and surest ways to pursue that passion. He also believes it is very important to make the right decisions at critical junctures, as well as having fun while following one's goal.

did.unittitle: Hawkins, Jeff, Outsourcing
