scopecontent.p: Hawkins shares his views on outsourcing and discusses how his company decides when and how to outsource. He believes that since the world is becoming global, outsourcing is the right thing to do.

did.unittitle: Hawkins, Jeff, Hiring Plan

scopecontent.p: Hawkins discusses the importance of having a planned hiring process while starting any new business. He goes on to say that the people who have not only seen the positives and the growth of the company, but have also lived through the rough and tough times with the company, make the best entrepreneurs.

did.unittitle: Hawkins, Jeff, Importance of Going Slow

scopecontent.p: Hawkins believes that most companies go out of business because they grow rapidly rather than pacing themselves while growing.

did.unittitle: Shader, Danny, Importance of Board Members

scopecontent.p: Danny Shader, CEO and president of Good Technology, believes that the board and its members provide a lot of value to a start-up venture. He shares his experience on managing the board in his company.

did.unittitle: Shader, Danny, Motivating Your People

scopecontent.p: Shader talks about how he keeps his employees motivated. He makes everyone in his company realize that they are all working together on something that is more important than any individual effort.

did.unittitle: Shader, Danny, Entrepreneur-in-Residence

scopecontent.p: Shader shares his entrepreneur-in-residence experience and his motivation behind starting it.

did.unittitle: Shader, Danny, Adding Value to Companies

scopecontent.p: Bill Campbell, former CEO of Intuit, talks about his role of adding value in start-up companies like Good Technology as well as established companies, like Google, that already have management teams.

did.unittitle: Hawkins, Trip, Persistence and The Notion of the Big Idea

dao.title: Persistence and The Notion of the Big Idea

daodesc.p: Persistence and The Notion of the Big Idea

scopecontent.p: Hawkins, Trip, chairman and CEO of Digital Chocolate, believes that persistence is a very important quality in entrepreneurs. It helps to overcome road-blocks and stick to one's beliefs no matter what others say, he adds. He talks about the notion of the big idea - doing something different than what everybody else is doing or something that nobody has thought of.

did.unittitle: Hawkins, Trip, Real-world Learning

scopecontent.p: Hawkins talks about how he started his first company while he was in college and the lessons he learnt from that experience. Real-world learning along with book and school type learning are instrumental in one's preparation to be an entrepreneur, he says.

did.unittitle: Hawkins, Trip, Challenges for an Entrepreneur

scopecontent.p: Hawkins explains how introspection is necessary for entrepreneurs to figure out when one is right and wrong.

did.unittitle: Hawkins, Trip, Learning from Mistakes

scopecontent.p: Hawkins offers suggestions on how to assess one's mistakes and figure out what to learn from them. It is okay to make mistakes but it is also important to learn from those mistakes and not repeat them again, he adds.

did.unittitle: Byers, Thomas (Thomas H.), Difference Between an Idea and an Opportunity

dao.title: Difference Between an Idea and an Opportunity

daodesc.p: Difference Between an Idea and an Opportunity

scopecontent.p: Byers, Tom, professor at Stanford University and founder and a faculty director of the Stanford Technology Ventures Program (STVP), stresses that "Entrepreneurs are not born, they are made". He discusses a framework that elaborates the difference between an idea and an opportunity.

did.unittitle: Byers, Thomas (Thomas H.), Why do Ventures Require Dynamic Leaders?

dao.title: Why do Ventures Require Dynamic Leaders?

daodesc.p: Why do Ventures Require Dynamic Leaders?

scopecontent.p: Byers strongly believes that entrepreneurs have to evolve with their organization. He uses a metaphor to compare entrepreneurs to three kinds of dogs: retriever, bloodhound, and husky, as they evole into the role of CEOs.

did.unittitle: Byers, Thomas (Thomas H.), Role of Context in High-Tech Venturing

dao.title: Role of Context in High-Tech Venturing

daodesc.p: Role of Context in High-Tech Venturing

scopecontent.p: Byers believes there are various events that are not within the control of a management team. Good entrepreneurs are those who find a way to navigate and deal with this 'context,' he adds.

did.unittitle: Byers, Thomas (Thomas H.), Market Positioning and the Importance of Partnerships

dao.title: Market Positioning and the Importance of Partnerships

daodesc.p: Market Positioning and the Importance of Partnerships

scopecontent.p: Byers believes that the impact of marketing is often underestimated by companies. He talks about how partnering is one of the keys to crossing the chasm between the early market and the mainstream market.

did.unittitle: Byers, Thomas (Thomas H.), Purpose of a Business Plan

scopecontent.p: Byers talks about how a great business plan can be developed. He uses Sahlman's alignment model to explain that an opportunity has to be in alignment with resources, people and context for deals to get completed.

did.unittitle: Byers, Thomas (Thomas H.), Importance of Cash Flow

scopecontent.p: Byers explains that smaller companies need to pay extra attention on how they spend their cash because if they run out of cash, it is game over for them. Byers uses the example of Palm Inc. to show how well the company managed their cash flow.

did.unittitle: Byers, Thomas (Thomas H.), What are the Essentials of the Venture Finance Process?

dao.title: What are the Essentials of the Venture Finance Process?

daodesc.p: What are the Essentials of the Venture Finance Process?

scopecontent.p: Byers goes over the essentials of a venture finance process: angel investors, corporate venture capital, boot strapping and the public. He also discusses the pros and cons of each of these pieces in this process.

did.unittitle: Byers, Thomas (Thomas H.), Characteristics of Entrepreneurs

scopecontent.p: Along with being audacious, courageous, patient, and adaptive, Byers believes that entrepreneurs should be exceptionally good at sales.

did.unittitle: Byers, Thomas (Thomas H.), Role of Ethics in High-Tech Entrepreneurship

dao.title: Role of Ethics in High-Tech Entrepreneurship

daodesc.p: Role of Ethics in High-Tech Entrepreneurship

scopecontent.p: Byers gives his perspective on how ethics played a role in high-tech entrepreneurship in the late 90's. He strongly believes that it is okay to fail but at the end of the day, it is character that matters.

did.unittitle: Davis, Geoff, What is Microfinance?

scopecontent.p: Davis, Geoff, founder and CEO of Unitus, explains the meaning of microfinance and the huge potential and impact the field has. He goes on to discuss the difference between microfinance and micro credit. He reveals that microfinance has a huge growth opportunity as it is potentially a five billion dollar market and is currently about a one billion dollar market.

did.unittitle: Davis, Geoff, Role of Unitus

scopecontent.p: Davis talks about how he got involved in micro credit and how it led to the formation of Unitus. He explains how Unitus is different form Grameen Bank, a pioneer in the field of microfinance. Unitus uses an Acceleration Model, a venture approach to do micro finance. This means they invest in programs around the world that offer micro loans and that have high growth potential to accelerate their growth.

did.unittitle: Davis, Geoff, Micro credit - A profitable business?

scopecontent.p: Davis believes that microfinance institutions can be profitable. This is a business opportunity with incredible social impact, he says.

did.unittitle: Davis, Geoff, Challenges Faced by Unitus

scopecontent.p: Davis talks about one of the biggest challenges he faced with Unitus: coming into an established industry that has been successful and showing that things can be done differently and better.

did.unittitle: Davis, Geoff, Following Your Gut

scopecontent.p: Set your sights high and go for it, says Davis. He encourages students who want to make a difference to believe and follow their dreams with grit and ingenuity.

did.unittitle: Davis, Geoff, Prodding Small Companies to Think Big

dao.title: Prodding Small Companies to Think Big

daodesc.p: Prodding Small Companies to Think Big

scopecontent.p: Davis discusses how Unitus helps transform small non-profit companies into large profitable companies. Unitus makes the companies think bigger and expand their vision. They try to paint the picture of a possibility of a bigger future, he notes.

did.unittitle: Williams, Evan, Advent of Podcasting

scopecontent.p: Williams, Evan, co-founder of Pyra Labs, creators of Blogger, talks about podcasting and how it started. He believes that due to the "webification" of audio, podcasting has become exciting and popular.

did.unittitle: Williams, Evan, Future of Podcasting

scopecontent.p: Williams believes that podcasting has just begun and that it is going to grow in the coming years. He explains that people are now only in the 'geocities' phase where they know how to access content but do not know why to do so or do so on an ongoing basis.

did.unittitle: Williams, Evan, Dealing with Competition

scopecontent.p: Williams gives his views on the evolving competitive landscape in podcasting. He believes that in a new, emerging market, it is about 'growing the pie' and bringing many players into the market to educate the people about the impact and usefulness of the new technology.

did.unittitle: Williams, Evan, Advice to Aspiring Entrepreneurs

scopecontent.p: Williams advices budding entrepreneurs to start small and think big. You should start with something small and something that you care about, he says. Smaller problems can be solved faster and can be eventually scaled into a big company, he adds.

did.unittitle: Williams, Evan, Learning from Failure

scopecontent.p: Williams talks about some of his biggest failures and what he learned from them. One of the things he has learned is the importance of building, collaborating and motivating a team.

did.unittitle: Williams, Evan, Maintaining Focus

scopecontent.p: Williams believes that one of the challenges he faced from very early on was of maintaining focus. He explains that he now has to be more disciplined due to various external diversions.

did.unittitle: Williams, Evan, Can Entrepreneurship be Taught?

scopecontent.p: Williams believes that entrepreneurship can be taught as it is a combination of skills and intense desires that drive a person to overcome challenges.

did.unittitle: Beaver, Bobby, Passion and Vision

scopecontent.p: Entrepreneurs must have passion. Passion and vision are the things entrepreneurs fall back on when their company goes through highs and lows. Bobby Beaver, vice president of technology at Zazzle, explains that the reasons for starting a venture should not be monetary but it should be passion - deep caring for a problem and the drive to solve the problem.

did.unittitle: Beaver, Bobby, Confidence in Small Teams

scopecontent.p: Beaver says that one of the most important lessons he has learned at Zazzle is to have confidence in yourself and your team.

did.unittitle: Beaver, Bobby, Question Everything

scopecontent.p: Beaver tells entrepreneurs to question everything people are telling them to do. Do not accept the status quo, he says. Do not give in to the notion that if it is has been done a certain way, you have to do it the same way, he adds.

did.unittitle: Beaver, Bobby, Adapt or Die

scopecontent.p: Beaver talks about how it is necessary for every company to adapt at every step as it grows, depending on the competitive landscape or technological advances, to make the most of opportunities along the way.

did.unittitle: Beaver, Bobby, People and Culture of Zazzle

scopecontent.p: Beaver believes nothing is more important for a company than the people that comprise it. This is why the Zazzle founders stress culture in their company. They constantly try to infuse values of innovation and empowerment amongst their people. Along with all this, the company also incorporates having fun to make sure their employees are enjoying the ride at Zazzle.

did.unittitle: Fraser, Janice, Choosing Your Partners

scopecontent.p: Fraser, Janice, CEO and a founding partner of Adaptive Path, believes one should choose partners based on who you want to go to when the going gets rough. She talks about the importance of a solid partnership.

did.unittitle: Fraser, Janice, Coping with Failures

scopecontent.p: Fraser believes being an entrepreneur is not a job but a mission. On this journey towards achieveing this mission, you are going to be faced with failures and successes, she says. It is the failures that inform the successes, she adds.

did.unittitle: Fraser, Janice, Protecting the Culture

scopecontent.p: Fraser calls culture the software of her company. She believes it is very important to protect and care for the culture of a company when it is evolving past its nascent stage.

did.unittitle: Fraser, Janice, Creating Meaning for Employees

scopecontent.p: Fraser believes that besides creating meaning for the world, an entrepreneurial venture should be able to create meaning for the people who comprise it as well. In this regard, people are able to passionately and zealously work toward making the company and product successful.

did.unittitle: Fraser, Janice, Decision-making

scopecontent.p: The efficiency of decision-making is very important to the management of any company. Fraser calls it a kind of 3-legged stool of responsibility, accountability and authority.

did.unittitle: Fraser, Janice, Alignment and People

scopecontent.p: Fraser believes alignment is the underlying principle to everthing we do. The work has to be fulfilling for the people who work in entreprenuerial ventures, she says. It is important to create an environment where people can excel.

did.unittitle: Fraser, Janice, Managing a Technology-Driven Company

scopecontent.p: Fraser discusses her experience as a non-technical person heading a technology driven company. She strongly believes that every manager should be able to lead people who are unlike them to have a successful company.

did.unittitle: Popovits, Kim, Recruiting a Passionate, All-Star Team

scopecontent.p: Popovits, Kim, President and Chief Operating Officer of Genomic Health, talks about how the strength of Genomic Health is its all star team, comprising of A players, who share a common passion of wanting to make a difference. Popovits believes that it is very important to share values and passion with your colleagues to make decision-making in organizations easier.

did.unittitle: Popovits, Kim, Focusing On Culture

scopecontent.p: Popovits talks about the importance of nurturing the culture at an organization. The people and the culture of Genomic Health form the core of the company. It is necessary to stop and celebrate the small and the big successes,she says, and to enjoy what you are doing to keep your company motivated and driven.

did.unittitle: Bartz, Carol, Tailoring Products for Different Consumer Groups

dao.title: Tailoring Products for Different Consumer Groups

daodesc.p: Tailoring Products for Different Consumer Groups

scopecontent.p: Bartz, Carol, chairman of the board, president and CEO of Autodesk, talks about the need to speak with customers to tailor a standard product for different customer groups. She uses the example of AutoCad and the way it has been tailored to specific customers to meet their requirements. She also says that the best way to make a product a standard is to get it to volume.

did.unittitle: Bartz, Carol, Being Successful in the Global Economy

dao.title: Being Successful in the Global Economy

daodesc.p: Being Successful in the Global Economy

scopecontent.p: Autodesk prices and packages its products differently in different countries. Bartz discusses how Autodesk has been successful doing business in emerging markets. She talks about the importance of looking at wage standards and labor standards of the country when selling global products like AutoCad across the world.

did.unittitle: Bartz, Carol, Stay Interested

scopecontent.p: According to Bartz, the more interested you are in things around the world, the more interesting you are to somebody else. Make sure your learning curve is always up and to the right, she adds.

did.unittitle: Bartz, Carol, Making Lemonade: Coping Strategies for Corporate Stresses

dao.title: Making Lemonade: Coping Strategies for Corporate Stresses

daodesc.p: Making Lemonade: Coping Strategies for Corporate Stresses

scopecontent.p: Bartz, Carol, CEO of Autodesk for many years, underlines the silver lining for many stagnating issues in the workplace. Making a plan for yourself is a good idea, but don't let it limit your scope. By bringing value to the organization, you are the one to benefit most. Learning is the most critical aspect of any job; if you're not growing, it's time to uproot. She also points out that bad managers are great teachers, as they are instructive in what not to do when you finally get to fill their role.

did.unittitle: Bartz, Carol, Pyramids, Not Ladders

scopecontent.p: In this clip, Bartz, Carol points out that young workers needn't be afraid of a lateral career move. Ambition often focuses only on upward motion, whereas well-rounded experience in a number of departments - sales, marketing, or customer service, just to name a few - gives a career a solid foundation. Ladders are unstable, Bartz says, but pyramids have depth, safety, and strength.

did.unittitle: Goldberg, Michael, Starting out as a Sole Founder

dao.title: Starting out as a Sole Founder

daodesc.p: Starting out as a Sole Founder

scopecontent.p: Goldberg, Michaell, General Partner at Mohr Davidow Ventures and Founder of Axion Inc., discusses his transition from being a venture capitalist to an entrepreneur. He left the venture capital industry to found a company. As a sole founder, he encourages everybody to start a company with at least one co-founder because it entails a difficult and lonely path.

did.unittitle: Goldberg, Michael, Selling a Venture

scopecontent.p: Goldberg talks about the point when he sold the company that he had built for nine years. He goes on to reveal that he would do the same thing then if he knew what he knows today. He says he was happy he sold the company to a bigger company who earned larger revenues on it.

did.unittitle: Goldberg, Michael, Role of Boards

scopecontent.p: Being on the boards of various companies, Goldberg gives his perspective and a sense of the flavor of what happens in board rooms and the roles of different types of boards.

did.unittitle: Goldberg, Michael, Conflict Between Management Team and Board Members

dao.title: Conflict Between Management Team and Board Members

daodesc.p: Conflict Between Management Team and Board Members

scopecontent.p: Goldberg talks about what happens when there is a conflict between board members and the management team in terms of the direction of the company.

did.unittitle: Goldberg, Michael, Importance of Patents and Intellectual Property

dao.title: Importance of Patents and Intellectual Property

daodesc.p: Importance of Patents and Intellectual Property

scopecontent.p: Goldberg talks about how understanding the importance of intellectual property, patents, trademarks and copyrights is essential in today's industries.

did.unittitle: Goldberg, Michael, Career Advice

scopecontent.p: Goldberg advices students and young-budding entrepreneurs to follow their passions. You have to be passionate for your company to be able to persist and face the failures that come along the way, he says.

did.unittitle: Goldberg, Michael, Patenting Genes

scopecontent.p: Goldberg gives his views on whether genes should be patented along with an insight into open source biology.

did.unittitle: Lee, Chong-Moon, Coming to Silicon Valley

scopecontent.p: Lee, Chong-Moon, chairman and CEO of Ambex Venture Group, and founder of Diamond Multimedia Systems, talks about his humble beginnings and the frustrations in his family business in Korea that led him to make a journey to Silion Valley.

did.unittitle: Lee, Chong-Moon, Facing challenges

scopecontent.p: Lee reveals how he started his company, the hardships he faced and the persistance that drove him to achieve his goals.

did.unittitle: Lee, Chong-Moon, Never Give up spirit

scopecontent.p: Lee advices entrepreneurs to never give up, fight challenges with perseverance and have a crystal clear vision to be successful.

did.unittitle: Lee, Chong-Moon, Skills of an entrepreneur

scopecontent.p: Lee believes that leadership and dynamic managerial style are two important skills that every successful entrepreneurs must have. He goes on to discuss the necessary skill set that make a successful entrepreneur.

did.unittitle: Lee, Chong-Moon, Success and Failure

scopecontent.p: Lee talks about how winning and losing are parts of everyone's life. However, it is important to learn from each one of them as you go along, he says. The successes and failures that he went through helped him overcome challenges in his business.

did.unittitle: Lee, Chong-Moon, Change yourself constantly

scopecontent.p: According to Lee, you have to keep changing yourself constantly to be successful. He explains that the more you know the world, the more informed decisions you will be able to make.

did.unittitle: Liemandt, Joe, Starting a business during undergraduate study

dao.title: Starting a business during undergraduate study

daodesc.p: Starting a business during undergraduate study

scopecontent.p: Liemandt, Joe, founder, CEO and chairman of Trilogy, talks about why entrepreneurship is something everyone needs to do in their career. You will go from the highest highs to the lowest lows in a matter of minutes, he says, but it is the time that is the best and the worst of your life. He advices starting a business when you are an undergraduate student because you do not have a whole lot to lose.

did.unittitle: Liemandt, Joe, Perseverance: Sticking to your beliefs

scopecontent.p: Liemandt talks about how an entrepreneur's beliefs leads to success or failure. As long as you believe in your business, he says, you can persevere. You have to love what you are doing and be passionate about it, he adds.

did.unittitle: Liemandt, Joe, Guaranteeing Business Value to Customers

scopecontent.p: Liemandt talks about how Trilogy moved on from just producing the best enterprise software in the market to adding and guaranteeing business value for its customers.

did.unittitle: Liemandt, Joe, Sharing Your Passion

scopecontent.p: Liemandt discusses how leading a start-up is harder and more stressful than heading a big company. The most difficult thing about being the CEO of a big company is making sure that all the employees share the same vision and passion for the business.

did.unittitle: Rodan, Katie, Benefits of a Partnership

scopecontent.p: Rodan, Katie, co-developer of Proactiv Solution, talks about the benefits of her partnership. She says that it is great for her to have a partner with whom she can share everything and make decisions together to jointly run the business.

did.unittitle: Rodan, Katie, Discovering and Meeting Market Needs

scopecontent.p: Rodan reveals the process of discovering a product that would solve the acne problem that was not being met by any of the products in the market. The main goal was to develop a product that would be easily accessible to target customers.

did.unittitle: Rodan, Katie, The Value of Effective Market Research

dao.title: The Value of Effective Market Research

daodesc.p: The Value of Effective Market Research

scopecontent.p: Rodan, Katie of Proactiv Solutions discusses a personal anecdote with a critical session of market research. The experience sent her team back to the drawing board to revamp a product for adult acne - after revealing that women surveyed didn't think they had acne and didn't care for the product's fragrance. Rodan also discusses her initial resistance to conduct the survey, and the tremendous benefits that it can yield for the entrepreneur.

did.unittitle: Rodan, Katie, Raising Money and Importance of Licensing Your Product

dao.title: Raising Money and Importance of Licensing Your Product

daodesc.p: Raising Money and Importance of Licensing Your Product

scopecontent.p: Rodan gives an insight into the obstacles faced while raising money for Proactiv. She discusses the importance of licensing a product as a way of raising money for the company.

did.unittitle: Rodan, Katie, Infomercials - A Way to Reach Your Audience

dao.title: Infomercials - A Way to Reach Your Audience

daodesc.p: Infomercials - A Way to Reach Your Audience

scopecontent.p: Rodan talks about how infomercials were successful in reaching and re-educating the audience on how to solve their skin problems and in turn helped her company realize an unmet need.

did.unittitle: Rodan, Katie, Owning Your Product Formula

scopecontent.p: During product development, Rodan advices to own the formula of the product, which is an asset, and suggests not to lose ownership of it.

did.unittitle: Rodan, Katie, Growing the Organization

scopecontent.p: Rodan talks about building Proactiv Solutions, getting the right team together and working with a partner to run an organization.

did.unittitle: Roos, John, Simple Mission Statement

scopecontent.p: Roos, John, chief executive officer of Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati, recommends having a simple mission statement when thinking about a business. You have to know what you are good at, where your core strengths lie, have a game plan and then stick with it, he says.

did.unittitle: Roos, John, Focus on Building a Brand

scopecontent.p: Roos says that no matter what kind of industry you get into or the company you start, you should focus on building a brand because that is likely to pay off big time.

did.unittitle: Roos, John, The Three Circle Strategy

scopecontent.p: Roos shares the Three Circle Strategy used at Wilson Sonsini. He says it is important for all great companies to start out and keep to fairly straightforward strategies yet remain flexible with the moving times.

did.unittitle: Roos, John, Strengths of Silicon Valley

scopecontent.p: Roos strongly believes that the strength of Silicon Valley lies in the fact that it is built on merit and diversity. Additionally, the Valley is unique in that failure is not considered a stigma, he says.

did.unittitle: Roos, John, Silicon Valley: An Ecosystem

scopecontent.p: Roos talks about how Silicon Valley is an ecosystem where everyone knows each other and everyone feeds off of each other. It is important when you are starting a company that you want to tap into that ecosystem, he says.

did.unittitle: Roos, John, Silicon Valley: Changing with the times

dao.title: Silicon Valley: Changing with the times

daodesc.p: Silicon Valley: Changing with the times

scopecontent.p: Roos talks about how the industry in Silicon Valley keeps changing. From the 1970s, the era of the brick and mortar technology industry, the Valley has seen a boom in semiconductor companies and computer companies, followed by the era of information technology and the Internet in the 90s. In this transition, the Valley has become global, he adds.

did.unittitle: Roos, John, Career Advice: Five Takeaways

scopecontent.p: Roos gives five takeaways in his talk: 1) Take risks; 2) Don't be afraid to take a step back in your career if it will help you move forward in the long run; 3) Surround yourself with good people and give them credit; 4) Little things really matter; and 5) Integrity matters more than anything else.

did.unittitle: Seelig, Tina Lynn, Every Problem is an Opportunity

scopecontent.p: Seelig, Tina, Executive Director for the Stanford Technology Ventures Program, believes that every problem is an opportunity for a creative solution. The way you view any problem depends on your attitude.

did.unittitle: Seelig, Tina Lynn, Value Creation from Opportunities

scopecontent.p: Seelig, Tina, Executive Director of the Stanford Technology Ventures Program, walks us through a life-changing hands-on classroom activity where students are taught to identify opportunities in nooks and crannies. With five dollars in seed funding and two hours of execution, she reports on the success of the exercise, and that many students reaped over one hundred times the initial investment (and others built a business without using any funding at all). Look for problems around you, says Seelig, and convert them into opportunities that create value. Embrace the opportunity to challenge assumptions and identify true cultural, social, or technological need.

did.unittitle: Seelig, Tina Lynn, Luck and Success

scopecontent.p: The harder I work, the luckier I get, says Seelig. Get out there and put yourself in a position to make yourself lucky, she adds.

did.unittitle: Seelig, Tina Lynn, "Career Advice: Interests, Skills and Market"

scopecontent.p: Seelig says that it is best to find the intersection between your passion, your skills, and the market. Passion is necessary, but passion alone is not sufficient to pursue a career, she adds.

did.unittitle: Seelig, Tina Lynn, Risk-taking and Failure

scopecontent.p: According to Seelig, if you are not failing sometimes, then you are not taking enough risks. Silicon Valley supports a culture of risk taking and embraces failure. She encourages everyone to take risks and not to get daunted by the fear of failure.

did.unittitle: Seelig, Tina Lynn, Learning from Failure

scopecontent.p: Seelig often makes her students write failure resumes as a way to recognize the mistakes that they have made as well as the lessons they have learned from those mistakes.

did.unittitle: Seelig, Tina Lynn, Career Advice: Don't Wait to be Anointed

dao.title: Career Advice: Don't Wait to be Anointed

daodesc.p: Career Advice: Don't Wait to be Anointed

scopecontent.p: Seelig advices that just as entrepreneurs empower themselves, you too should not wait for someone to tell you that you are empowered to take on a new responsibility. Just do it, she adds.

did.unittitle: Seelig, Tina Lynn, Importance of Networking

scopecontent.p: Seelig believes that it is important to build relationships and network with the people you meet everyday. It is a small world and as you go through life you are going to meet the same people again and again, she adds.

did.unittitle: Seelig, Tina Lynn, Balancing Priorities

scopecontent.p: Seelig talks about the importance of figuring out and balancing priorities. She believes it is necessary to reassess your priorities frequently, selecting a few things to focus on.

did.unittitle: Seelig, Tina Lynn, Working in Teams

scopecontent.p: Seelig believes that while working in a team it is important to make everyone else on your team successful.

did.unittitle: Seelig, Tina Lynn, Be Fabulous!

scopecontent.p: According to Seelig, never miss an opportunity to be fabulous! She encourages everyone to embrace this idea and to help make the world a better place.

did.unittitle: Marrone, Pam, The Founding of AgraQuest

scopecontent.p: Marrone, Pam, founder and former Chairman/CEO of AgraQuest Inc., talks about how she turned her childhood passion and love for bugs into a lifelong commitment that led her to found AgraQuest.

did.unittitle: Marrone, Pam, Creating Need for Your Product

scopecontent.p: Marrone describes the impact of AgraQuest on the global bio-pesticide market.

did.unittitle: Marrone, Pam, Overview of AgraQuest

scopecontent.p: Marrone gives an overview of AgraQuest and talks about how the company has differentiated itself in the pesticide industry.

did.unittitle: Marrone, Pam, Navigating AgraQuest's Value Chain

scopecontent.p: Marrone faced a lot of skepticism and obstacles while developing AgraQuest's products. She overcame these barriers by demonstrating the effectiveness of her product on the fields of farmers as well as hiring hungry dogs as salespeople to push the product into the market.

did.unittitle: Marrone, Pam, The Product Vision

scopecontent.p: Marrone formed focus groups to change policies to ammend incorrect artificial testing procedures carried out by academic scientists to test the efficacy of AgraQuest's product.

did.unittitle: Marrone, Pam, Understanding Your Customer

scopecontent.p: Marrone reveals that the trick to making the adoption curve steeper and faster is to focus the product on an unmet need where there is little competition.

did.unittitle: Marrone, Pam, Negotiation: Be in a Position of Strength

dao.title: Negotiation: Be in a Position of Strength

daodesc.p: Negotiation: Be in a Position of Strength

scopecontent.p: Marrone advices to always plan for disaster and to be in a position of strength while negotiating.

did.unittitle: Marrone, Pam, Lessons Learned

scopecontent.p: Marrone shares the lessons that she learned at AgraQuest. She strongly believes in a diverse, trustworthy workforce and hiring people who believe in the product.

did.unittitle: Marrone, Pam, Working with AgraQuest

scopecontent.p: Marrone discusses why working at AgraQuest is better than working at any other company.

did.unittitle: Smith, Lonnie, Technology Adoption

scopecontent.p: Smith, Lonnie, President and Chief Executive Officer of Intuitive Surgical, uses Moore, Geoffrey's "Crossing the Chasm" model to explain the adoption of technology amongst surgeons.

did.unittitle: Smith, Lonnie, Patient Adoption Curve

scopecontent.p: Smith discusses how patients have adopted Intuitive Surgical's new technology.

did.unittitle: Smith, Lonnie, Patent Battles: First-Mover Advantage

scopecontent.p: Smith talks about how being the first mover in the market has given Intuitive Surgical an upper-hand in patent battles.

did.unittitle: Keller-Bottom, Stephanie, Collaborate to Enter Markets

scopecontent.p: Keller-Bottom, Stephanie, Director of Nokia Innovent, discusses how companies need to collaborate to bring their products to the market. She talks about the value that entrepreneurs bring to large companies as they understand the importance of collaboration in order to leverage resources.

did.unittitle: Keller-Bottom, Stephanie, Separation from Nokia's Core Business

scopecontent.p: According to Keller-Bottom, when you are in a big company and trying to do something that differs with the core business of the company, then you are going to face a lot of resistance early on. Innovent faced this when it differentiated itself from the core business of Nokia, she says.

did.unittitle: Keller-Bottom, Stephanie, Building Your Business

scopecontent.p: Keller-Bottom shares some of the lessons learned while Innovent was growing. She says it was very important to work with competitors as collaborators as well as lead a very passionate team effectively during the development of the business.

did.unittitle: Keller-Bottom, Stephanie, Picking Your Partners and Your Team

dao.title: Picking Your Partners and Your Team

daodesc.p: Picking Your Partners and Your Team

scopecontent.p: Keller-Bottom advises entrepreneurs to find partners who share the same values and direction that you and your management team have. Also, she emphasizes how vital it is to have an exit strategy and aligned assets.

did.unittitle: Keller-Bottom, Stephanie, Focus, Flexibility and Market Validation

scopecontent.p: Keller-Bottom recommends entrepreneurs to stay focused and be flexible. Find partners who complement and will add value to your business, she says. She talks about the importance of doing a market validation study to determine the market and design a pricing strategy.

did.unittitle: Keller-Bottom, Stephanie, Creating Commercial Value for Your Product

dao.title: Creating Commercial Value for Your Product

daodesc.p: Creating Commercial Value for Your Product

scopecontent.p: Keller-Bottom demonstrates how the trajectory of a new company appears. She says that a product has to iterate several times from the product development stage until it enters the market.

did.unittitle: Keller-Bottom, Stephanie, Working with Your Investor

scopecontent.p: Keller-Bottom advises that while working with investors it is important to pay attention to the valuation methodology, as that will determine the amount of money an entrepreneur will make.

did.unittitle: Keller-Bottom, Stephanie, Learning from History

scopecontent.p: Keller-Bottom gives entrepreneurs some tips and asks them to learn from history and understand the market to help shape their businesses.

did.unittitle: Zuckerberg, Mark, 1984-, Product Development at Facebook

scopecontent.p: Zuckerberg, Mark, founder of TheFacebook, gives an example to demonstrate product development and experience at Facebook and talks about how their product has evolved with the company.

did.unittitle: Zuckerberg, Mark, 1984-, Team Dynamics

scopecontent.p: Zuckerberg discusses the evolution of Facebook's founding team from a bunch of college friends to a large team of several engineers, its changing dynamics and his role as a leader in the company.

did.unittitle: Zuckerberg, Mark, 1984-, Hiring the Right People

scopecontent.p: Facebook Founder Zuckerberg, Mark reveals the individual skills and the balance of experience he looks for when recruiting college graduates, while still building and moving his company forward.

did.unittitle: Zuckerberg, Mark, 1984-, Generating Revenue

scopecontent.p: An early interview with Zuckerberg, Mark at the dawn of Facebook's popularity unveils the opportunities that surface from a mammoth amount of page views and sticky user loyalty. A hot web property can reel in millions in ad revenue alone.

did.unittitle: Zuckerberg, Mark, 1984-, Entrepreneurial Skills Learned

scopecontent.p: Zuckerberg talks about the entrepreneurial skills he acquired in college that led him to building Facebook.

did.unittitle: Zuckerberg, Mark, 1984-, Listening Skills in an Entrepreneur

scopecontent.p: Amongst his different entrepreneurial talents, Jim Breyer, Managing Partner of Accel Partners, talks about the importance of Zuckerberg's listening skills that have helped him effectively lead Facebook to success.

did.unittitle: Zuckerberg, Mark, 1984-, Investing in New Ideas

scopecontent.p: Breyer discusses why Accel Partners decided to invest in Facebook and what they look for in new ideas before they convert them into ventures.

did.unittitle: Zuckerberg, Mark, 1984-, Free Time Fosters Free Thinking

scopecontent.p: People can't be forced to be friends, notes Facebook founder Zuckerberg, Mark, but innovative entrepreneurs can facilitate a friendly work environment. He attributes part of his enterprise's success to casual, unstructured communication woven into the work day. His hope? To create the space for co-workers to freely associate ideas and stretch their imagination.

did.unittitle: Zuckerberg, Mark, 1984-, Challenges Going Forward

scopecontent.p: Zuckerberg and Breyer discuss the ongoing challenges they face and the tradeoffs they have to make as Facebook continues to grow and evolve.

did.unittitle: Polese, Kim, Setting Up Infrastructure

scopecontent.p: Polese, Kim, CEO of SpikeSource, relates the challenges she learned while starting a company. She realized that though entrepreneurs might see potential in their technology and have the right people in their company, that alone will not ensure success in the marketplace. It requires making sure that all the pieces are in place for that company, she says.

did.unittitle: Polese, Kim, Birth of Java

scopecontent.p: Polese describes the development of Java at Sun and the various things that made it a success.

did.unittitle: Polese, Kim, Solving a Real Problem

scopecontent.p: According to Polese, SpikeSource is solving a real problem, which makes it really exciting.

did.unittitle: Polese, Kim, Popularity of Open Source

scopecontent.p: Polese discusses why open source is popular amongst venture capitalists.

did.unittitle: Polese, Kim, Importance of the Community and Data and Process Automation in Businesses

dao.title: Importance of the Community and Data and Process Automation in Businesses

daodesc.p: Importance of the Community and Data and Process Automation in Businesses

scopecontent.p: Polese empahsizes working with the community and the role of data and process automation in business.

did.unittitle: Polese, Kim, Software as a Service

scopecontent.p: Polese talks about how software has transitioned from a product that generates revenue to a service. She sees the software industry slowly shifting towards this idea.

did.unittitle: Polese, Kim, Value of the Long Tail

scopecontent.p: Polese explains the concept of the "long tail".

did.unittitle: Polese, Kim, Lessons Learned

scopecontent.p: Polese shares some lessons learned along the way and gives advice to budding entrepreneurs to never stop learning and to find the right people and the right idea for their business.

did.unittitle: Polese, Kim, Ethics in Business

scopecontent.p: Polese talks about the importance of being ethical and not being evil while running a business.

did.unittitle: Polese, Kim, When Should You Open Source?

scopecontent.p: Polese believes that entrepreneurs should open source their proprietary software only if the open source supports and enables their core business.

did.unittitle: Ricks, Frank, Thinking About Entrepreneurship

scopecontent.p: Frank reveals how he started thinking of entrepreneurship at a young age. He believes that if you don't have it, you just make it!

did.unittitle: Ricks, Frank, Game Plan at LRK

scopecontent.p: Frank shares the game plan they have adopted at their architectural firm.

did.unittitle: Ricks, Frank, Role of Multidisciplinary Teams

scopecontent.p: Frank emphasizes the importance of having a multidisciplinary team and talks about how it has helped them solve problems in different companies like FedEx.

did.unittitle: Ricks, Frank, Mission Statement and Culture Transfer

scopecontent.p: Frank describes the mission statement and the principles they follow at LRK Architecture. He goes on to talk about the issue of perpetuating the company's culture as the company grows.

did.unittitle: Ricks, Frank, Orbiting the Giant Hairball

scopecontent.p: Ricks, Frank, founding principal of Looney Ricks Kiss Architects, explains the concept of the hairball and recommends the book "Orbiting the Giant Hairball", to entrepreneurs interested in starting a business of any size.

did.unittitle: Ricks, Frank, Attracting Clients Early On

scopecontent.p: Ricks advices entrepreneurs on how to attract clients in the early days of a firm when a company is trying to compete and it does not have any accomplishments to talk about .

did.unittitle: Mayer, Marissa, 1975-, Ideas Come From Everywhere

scopecontent.p: Mayer, Marissa, Google's Vice President of Search Products & User Experience, believes that ideas for new products come from everywhere - every employee, every department, from both necessity and serendipity. By creating an environment where ideas can be freely exercised, like a muscle they will likely get more toned and more in tune with the organization's circulation.

did.unittitle: Mayer, Marissa, 1975-, Give Ideas Credit, Not Credit for Ideas

dao.title: Give Ideas Credit, Not Credit for Ideas

daodesc.p: Give Ideas Credit, Not Credit for Ideas

scopecontent.p: Both the enterprise and the end users are better served by a culture that revolves around rewarding great ideas, rather than the self-promotion of getting others to acknowledge the contributions of an individual. Mayer, Marissa, Vice President of Search Products & User Experience at Google, believes that if you fill a room with smart people and give them access to information, brilliant ideas will flourish, and the need for a strict management hierarchy dissolves. A platform for the free-form sharing of ideas promotes an open culture and a flat organization.

did.unittitle: Mayer, Marissa, 1975-, Work with Smart People

scopecontent.p: Challenge yourself against better players and you'll become star of the team. Google's Vice President of Location and Services, Mayer, Marissa, reflects on her personal experience working with some of the finest talent in high-tech, and points out that working with the best empowers each player to excel.

did.unittitle: Mayer, Marissa, 1975-, License to Pursue Dreams

scopecontent.p: Passion and momentum build when skilled employees have access to great tools and the time to stretch them in new directions. Mayer, Marissa, Vice President of Search Products & User Experience at Google, discusses the groundbreaking company practice of setting aside 20 percent of an employee's time for creative projects. By her own assessment, nearly half of the company's most recent launches came from ideas sparked during this unstructured time.

did.unittitle: Mayer, Marissa, 1975-, Learning From Mistakes

scopecontent.p: Madonna had The Sex Book. Apple had the Newton. Mayer, Marissa, Vice President of Search Products & User Experience for Google, points out that all the best brands, including her own, have made some tremendous product errors. But what allows an enterprise to endure, she says, is its ability to learn from its mistakes and make corrections. Performance is what's important, even if it's not instantaneous.

did.unittitle: Mayer, Marissa, 1975-, Data is Apolitical

scopecontent.p: Product decisions can be based on the company politics. But one cannot argue with facts and stats, and this is the basis, says Mayer, Marissa, Google's Vice President of Search Products & User Experience, by which the company bases its decisions. Google's approach is the take the guesswork out of product design, from functionality to shades of color, and they believe in the science of well-monitored and frequent A/B testing.

did.unittitle: Mayer, Marissa, 1975-, Creativity Loves Constraint

scopecontent.p: In product development, Google's Mayer, Marissa, Vice President of Search Products & User Experience, believes that a small amount of constraint - whether in file size, pixels, or speed - fosters a lot of innovation. The lesson she shares? Too much creative freedom can make creativity unfocused. A solution with a strict set of barriers yields more concrete solutions.

did.unittitle: Mayer, Marissa, 1975-, Bank Users, Not Money

scopecontent.p: Google has proven that if you build it, they will come, and their mass of tools to keep users logged in has been the crux of their success. Vice President of Search Products & User Experience Mayer, Marissa elaborates on this strategy, pointing out that money - and advertisers - will always follow consumers. Focus on building sticky media that draws in a wide audience, and the method to its monetization will follow.

did.unittitle: Mayer, Marissa, 1975-, Don't Kill Projects; Morph Them

scopecontent.p: Repackage, rejuvenate, re-market, and re-examine those products or practices you thought would fly, and craft them a new set of wings. Vice President of Search Products & User Experience, Mayer, Marissa lives by the old adage that if at first you don't succeed, try again. She pushes aspiring business thinkers to breathe new life into failed ventures, as opposed to cutting the cord.

did.unittitle: Mayer, Marissa, 1975-, Surviving the Bubble

scopecontent.p: Mayer, Marissa, Google's Vice President of Search Products & User Experience, says that when people visit their corporate offices, they feel as if the dotcom bubble never burst. But what differentiates Google from all of the other defunct dotcom's? Profitability. This critical differentiation is the obvious and most basic capability of the company's success.

did.unittitle: Phelan, Ryan, Importance of Information in the Medical Field

dao.title: Importance of Information in the Medical Field

daodesc.p: Importance of Information in the Medical Field

scopecontent.p: Phelan, Ryan, founder and CEO of DNA Direct, talks about the vitality and the role of information in the medical field.

did.unittitle: Phelan, Ryan, Starting a Business

scopecontent.p: Phelan discusses some of the hardships that come along with starting a business.

did.unittitle: Phelan, Ryan, Power of Genetics

scopecontent.p: Phelan believes that genetics will make a big impact among consumers in the coming future.

did.unittitle: Phelan, Ryan, What is Social Entrepreneurship?

scopecontent.p: Phelan describes the meaning of social entrepreneurship.

did.unittitle: Penchina, Gil, Joining eBay

scopecontent.p: Penchina, Gil, CEO of Wikia, talks about the things that attracted him to eBay and the vision he had of where the company was going when he joined.

did.unittitle: Penchina, Gil, Transformation of a Start-up

scopecontent.p: Penchina discusses how a start-up like eBay has transformed over time to a big company.

did.unittitle: Penchina, Gil, Working in a Start-up

scopecontent.p: Penchina shares his thoughts on the differences in working in a start-up versus a big company and the skills he leveraged while moving from a big company like eBay to Wikia.

did.unittitle: Penchina, Gil, Angel Investing

scopecontent.p: Penchina discusses his interest and involvement in angel investing.

did.unittitle: Penchina, Gil, Career Advice

scopecontent.p: Penchina emphasizes the importance of people skills and reveals some lessons he wish he knew when he was in school.

did.unittitle: Penchina, Gil, Learning from Failures

scopecontent.p: Penchina shares some of his failures and discusses lessons learned from them.

did.unittitle: Penchina, Gil, Entering a Global Market

scopecontent.p: Wikia CEO Penchina, Gil discusses the steps that entrepreneurs should take when entering a new and unfamiliar global market.

did.unittitle: Penchina, Gil, Skills Learned in School

scopecontent.p: Penchina describes the exact facts and skills he learned in engineering school and business school that he finds useful today while running his business.

did.unittitle: Penchina, Gil, Finding Entrepreneurs

scopecontent.p: Penchina discusses the process of finding entrepreneurs and then investing in them.

did.unittitle: Penchina, Gil, Luck: Combination of Timing and Preparation

dao.title: Luck: Combination of Timing and Preparation

daodesc.p: Luck: Combination of Timing and Preparation

scopecontent.p: Penchina attributes most of his success to luck, which he believes is a combination of good timing and some preparation. He says that he has been able to get to where he wanted as he has consistently stuck to his plan.

did.unittitle: Eisenhardt, Kathleen M., Team Composition

scopecontent.p: Kathy Eisenhardt, co-director of Stanford Technology Ventures Program and professor in Management Science and Engineering, discusses the size and composition of successful teams. She recommends a team of 3-5 cross-functional people with diverse age group and experience.

did.unittitle: Eisenhardt, Kathleen M., Market Selection

scopecontent.p: Stanford Management Science & Engineering Professor Kathleen Eisenhardt defines and discusses different sized markets (emergent, growth and mature) and explains why growth markets are ideal for startups to enter.

did.unittitle: Eisenhardt, Kathleen M., Surfer Model of Venture Growth

scopecontent.p: Eisenhardt explains her findings about teams and markets using the Surfer Model of Venture Growth. In her research, she found that there is great synergy between great teams and great markets. The returns obtained by this pair dwarf any other combination.

did.unittitle: Eisenhardt, Kathleen M., The Art of Fundraising (Part 1)

scopecontent.p: Eisenhardt describes the key elements associated with successful fundraising. She discusses the importance of asking for the correct amount of money at the right time from the appropriate people.

did.unittitle: Eisenhardt, Kathleen M., The Art of Fundraising (Part 2)

scopecontent.p: Eisenhardt stresses the importance of researching regional VCs and understanding the true motives behind their interests.

did.unittitle: Eisenhardt, Kathleen M., Closing the Deal

scopecontent.p: Eisenhardt discusses how to negotiate with an investor and the importance of closing a deal. She stresses the need for having a credible alternative, which can be leveraged to speed up the process.

did.unittitle: Eisenhardt, Kathleen M., Creating Opportunities

scopecontent.p: Eisenhardt believes that markets are not chosen but created. She describes how this was successfully done at Amazon, eBay and Verisign. She explains that to be wildly successful it is important to become the cognitive referent to the market.

did.unittitle: Eisenhardt, Kathleen M., Protecting Your Market

scopecontent.p: Eisenhardt shares several strategies that a small company can use to protect their market. This includes marketing alliances, getting funded by larger competitors, and buying out smaller competitors.

did.unittitle: Eisenhardt, Kathleen M., Edge of Chaos

scopecontent.p: Eisenhardt shares her work on managing at the edge of chaos. She defines the edge of chaos as the perfect balance between being too structured and not having enough structure. In particular, she compares optimal strategies for the highly regulated and structured biotech market and the ambiguous mobile gaming market.

did.unittitle: Eisenhardt, Kathleen M., Balance of Structure and Ambiguity

scopecontent.p: Eisenhardt provides an example of where structure and ambiguity live in harmony at Yahoo.

did.unittitle: Wallace, Rick, The 3 Constituents: Investors, Customers and Employees

dao.title: The 3 Constituents: Investors, Customers and Employees

daodesc.p: The 3 Constituents: Investors, Customers and Employees

scopecontent.p: Wallace, Rick, the new CEO of KLA-Tencor shares his insights about managing a large organization. He describes his job as making trade-offs to ensure that all three constituents, investors, customers and employees, are happy with the company. While they all have separate and sometimes contradicting motivations, a company's long term success is heavily dependant on its ability to cater to these three constituencies.

did.unittitle: Wallace, Rick, Focus Focus Focus

scopecontent.p: Wallace, Rick describes the importance of focus for a start-up. While venturing in multiple markets can help diversify the risk, it is often disastrous for start-ups because they are already handicapped with limited resources. Rick talks about how focus helped put KLA-Tencor on the right track.

did.unittitle: Wallace, Rick, Follow the Business Model

scopecontent.p: Wallace, Rick shares the history of KLA-Tencor to show that it is important to follow one's business model. KLA revolutionized the industry by starting to charge for service instead of just offering it up for free. In order to enforce this, the founder had to risk losing IBM as a client. However, his bet paid off, and IBM finally agreed to pay for service. This has led to a large and profitable annuity stream for KLA-Tencor.

did.unittitle: Wallace, Rick, Creating an Entrepreneurial Environment Within a Large Company

dao.title: Creating an Entrepreneurial Environment Within a Large Company

daodesc.p: Creating an Entrepreneurial Environment Within a Large Company

scopecontent.p: Wallace, Rick shares his experience of being tasked with figuring out how to sell multiple machines per fab. He describes how his boss took away his major constraints, time and money, and incented him to take a risk. He has used a similar structure several times within the company to create an entrepreneurial and risk-taking environment within a large multi-billion dollar company.

did.unittitle: Wallace, Rick, Motivating Employees

scopecontent.p: Wallace, Rick shares his strategy for hiring and retaining talented employees. He claims that money is important, but the primary motivators for employees at KLA-Tencor are personal growth and fairness in rewards and recognition.

did.unittitle: Wallace, Rick, Managing Competition from Startups

scopecontent.p: Wallace describes the various steps he takes at KLA-Tencor to ensure that their technology doesn't get outdated by a fresh start-up. He discusses a unique organizational structure that fosters growth and innovation, an investment arm of the company which monitors start-ups, and large financial barriers to entry.

did.unittitle: McCracken, Joe, Genentech's Business Model

scopecontent.p: McCracken, Joe, Vice President of Business Development at Genentech, describes Genentech's business model where commercialization takes a back seat to science. He differentiates this from other typical pharmaceutical companies and shows how this affects the culture at Genentech. He credits this approach for the successful innovation of several hugely profitable drugs.

did.unittitle: McCracken, Joe, A Novel Approach Towards Sales and Research

dao.title: A Novel Approach Towards Sales and Research

daodesc.p: A Novel Approach Towards Sales and Research

scopecontent.p: Joe discusses innovative practices put in place in the sales and research organizations within Genentech. He cites the 20% free time and incentives for publishing for scientists and the focus of the sales force on at most two products as major reasons for Genentech's success both in the lab and the marketplace.

did.unittitle: McCracken, Joe, Why is Genentech the Best Company to Work for?

dao.title: Why is Genentech the Best Company to Work for?

daodesc.p: Why is Genentech the Best Company to Work for?

scopecontent.p: In 2006, Fortune ranked Genentech as the best company to work for. McCracken shares their secret: it is the empowerment of the employees and the validation of their hard work, which comes in the form of gratified patients.

did.unittitle: McCracken, Joe, Impact of Generics on the Biotechnology Industry

dao.title: Impact of Generics on the Biotechnology Industry

daodesc.p: Impact of Generics on the Biotechnology Industry

scopecontent.p: Joe comments on the widely held debate in the biotechnology industry about the legality and effectiveness of generic drugs. Joe feels that as long as the follow-on biologics are effective and safe, they would be great for the industry. He states the Genentech will compete by continually innovating better drugs.

did.unittitle: McCracken, Joe, Venture Capital in Biotech

scopecontent.p: Joe discusses the recent lack of investment in biotech. He explains that after the biotech bubble in 2000, VCs have been hesitant in investing in biotech companies, and this has led to a slowdown in innovation in the industry.

did.unittitle: Earl, Nick, Engineering Innovations in Gaming

scopecontent.p: Nick shows a video of a motion capture technique used in the latest video games. He stresses the need for such innovation in order to compete in a booming market.

did.unittitle: Earl, Nick, The Changing Economics in Mobile Gaming

dao.title: The Changing Economics in Mobile Gaming

daodesc.p: The Changing Economics in Mobile Gaming

scopecontent.p: Earl, Nick, General Manager of Electronic Arts Redwood Shores Studio, shares his insights about moving into the mobile gaming market. He explains that the high price of building graphical games is prohibitive in an environment where there is no hardware standardization.

did.unittitle: Earl, Nick, Challenges and Opportunities in Asia

scopecontent.p: Earl discusses the several challenges and mitigation strategies used when marketing to a variety of Asian countries. EA's strategy to overcome the IP protection problems is to take games online. He also discusses the need for different technology requirements to market in countries like South Korea where social networking is a key driver of sales.

did.unittitle: Earl, Nick, Opportunities for Start-ups

scopecontent.p: Earl shares his thoughts about the plausibility of starting a game development company in the current environment. He explains that with the release of new consoles and the growth in mobile technologies, it is a great time to start a company with a target audience in mind.

did.unittitle: Earl, Nick, Gaming in China

scopecontent.p: Earl discusses the importance of understanding and developing games for markets. EA started a studio in Shanghai to learn about China's gaming population. He also talks about protecting EA's IP via an online distribution mechanism.

did.unittitle: Larsen, Chris, The Emotional Roller Coaster

scopecontent.p: Chris Larsen, a veteran entrepreneur, CEO and co-founder of Prosper.com shares the ups and downs he faced during the first year and a half of starting Prosper.com. He stresses the importance of being empathetic while also staying focused on the task at hand.

did.unittitle: Larsen, Chris, Defensibility Through Regulatory Constraints

scopecontent.p: Larsen and Jim Breyer, Managing Partner at Accel Partners, stress the value of having approval in a regulated industry. This provides an excellent barrier to entry and is very attractive to VCs. Larsen draws on his experience from E-Loan and Prosper in suggesting that while it is cumbersome, if an idea is in the interest of the consumer, it is not difficult to obtain approval.

did.unittitle: Larsen, Chris, Importance of Building a Strong Culture

dao.title: Importance of Building a Strong Culture

daodesc.p: Importance of Building a Strong Culture

scopecontent.p: Larsen stresses the importance of having a strong positive culture. He believes that the consumer advocacy culture at E-Loan motivated employees even when the stock prices plummeted.

did.unittitle: Larsen, Chris, Managing the Burn Rate

scopecontent.p: Larsen and Breyer explain the lessons learned during the bubble. They suggest that it is important to spend frugally and get the maximum value for every dollar spent, regardless of the amount of money present in the bank.

did.unittitle: Larsen, Chris, Career Advice for Students about Entrepreneurship

dao.title: Career Advice for Students about Entrepreneurship

daodesc.p: Career Advice for Students about Entrepreneurship

scopecontent.p: Larsen and Breyer provide career advice to students. The most important thing is to be passionate about what you do, they say. They also suggest that the current economic environment is perfect for fresh graduates to take risks and follow their dreams.

did.unittitle: Seelig, Tina Lynn, The Puzzle Project: Entrepreneurship Simulation

scopecontent.p: This five minute video captures the essence of a two hour workshop in which student teams must reconstruct a jigsaw puzzle. Several puzzles are mixed together and the pieces distributed randomly to teams. The teams are urged to challenge assumptions, leverage resources, seize opportunities, pay attention to the market, and to create value. Every ten minutes the "market" changes. The video shows the set-up of the game, the action, and several minutes of debriefing with the teams. In this two hour exercise, students must develop a strategy, they need to collaborate and compete, they must negotiate and barter, they need to be creative, and they must divide the tasks at hand in order to create the most value.

did.unittitle: Kriens, Scott, Opportunity Recognition

scopecontent.p: Kriens, Scott describes how Juniper was able to take advantage of the rapidly growing internet router space. He states that Juniper's focus on solving unique problems helped them compete against other established players.

did.unittitle: Kriens, Scott, Capitalizing on Market Power

scopecontent.p: Scott stresses the role of the market and the benefits of leveraging its power to grow rapidly. He describes how Juniper grew to be a $1 Billion company within 3 years.

did.unittitle: Kriens, Scott, Attracting Talented People

scopecontent.p: Scott describes how the interview process at Juniper was designed to attract the best people. He encourages students to be excited about companies with really smart people instead of being intimidated by them.

did.unittitle: Kriens, Scott, Challenges of a Global Company

scopecontent.p: One of Juniper Networks's biggest challenges is efficiently operating a global company. CEO Kriens, Scott challenges the audience to obtain the skill set necessary to work in a global team environment.

did.unittitle: Kriens, Scott, Market Selection

scopecontent.p: Scott describes his experience at Stratacom where for the first 5 years the company lost a lot of money and had modest revenue growth, and then after some refocusing of resources, the company did really well and was eventually bought out for 5 billion dollars. He explains that what changed was their target market, and not the people in the company. He states that identifying markets with high growth and attaching oneself to such markets is very valuable.

did.unittitle: Kriens, Scott, The Ups and Downs of Being a CEO

dao.title: The Ups and Downs of Being a CEO

daodesc.p: The Ups and Downs of Being a CEO

scopecontent.p: A Silicon Valley veteran shares his wisdom and describes the ups and downs of his career. He stresses the importance of not getting caught up in the media, and instead staying focused on the task at hand.

did.unittitle: Kriens, Scott, Importance of Common Sense

scopecontent.p: Scott explains that it is important to "do the thing that makes the most sense". He uses JFK's lesson from the Bay of Pigs to illustrate this point.

did.unittitle: Kriens, Scott, Employee Growth

scopecontent.p: Scott shares his philosophy on giving people an opportunity to grow within the company. At Juniper, he chooses the most energetic and enthusiastic person instead of the most experienced one for a given project.

did.unittitle: Kriens, Scott, Value of Innovation

scopecontent.p: Scott suggests that basic questions such as why and for which market are asked before significant engineering resources can be allocated to any project. While Juniper's culture promotes innovation, it doesn't appreciate an innovation that is never used.

did.unittitle: Kriens, Scott, Net Neutrality

scopecontent.p: Scott shares his views on net neutrality, a topic of hot debate in the Internet space. He defines net neutrality and explains its impact.

did.unittitle: Ballard, Greg, Great Products Aren't Enough

scopecontent.p: Greg suggests that a good product is a solid foundation, but not enough to guarantee success. He illustrates his point using the examples of Betamax, and his own experience in competing with NVIDIA.

did.unittitle: Ballard, Greg, Value of Customer Service

scopecontent.p: As a seasoned Silicon Valley CEO, Greg states that one of the most important aspects of business is customer service. While this is often the most neglected, and the first to be cut when money is sparse, Greg suggests that saving money on providing great customer service is not a smart move.

did.unittitle: Ballard, Greg, Treat Everyone with Respect

scopecontent.p: An important lesson that Greg learned during his extensive career was to treat everyone with respect. He states that the business world is in fact a small world, and one is likely to interact with the same people many times. It is very important to be respectful of those senior and junior to you.

did.unittitle: Ballard, Greg, Agree and Commit, Disagree and Commit

dao.title: Agree and Commit, Disagree and Commit

daodesc.p: Agree and Commit, Disagree and Commit

scopecontent.p: Greg states that the most corrosive thing that can happen in a company is to have a debate continue after the decision has been made. He suggests that people who are supportive of decisions which they were against are very valuable to an organization.

did.unittitle: Ballard, Greg, Follow Your Values

scopecontent.p: Greg recounts scenarios where he could have made a little more money by abandoning his value system; however, he is happier for having stuck to his values. He suggests that the best way to make such decisions is to think about what the right thing to do is, and then do it.

did.unittitle: Ballard, Greg, Balancing Life With Business Needs

scopecontent.p: As someone who has spent more than his fair sharing working, Greg gives insight into how he maintains a strong work-life balance. He stresses the importance of prioritization and communication.

did.unittitle: Ballard, Greg, First to Market

scopecontent.p: Greg draws on his experiences at 3Dfx and GluMobile and states that being first to market is not necessarily an advantage. He suggests that it is often better to be second and thus learn from the mistakes of the previous entrants.

did.unittitle: Ballard, Greg, Creativity in Business

scopecontent.p: Greg suggests that there are many ways that creativity can manifest itself in business: from business strategy to product design to a clever marketing campaign. He states that a successful business requires creativity in all aspects of its operations.

did.unittitle: Seelig, Tina Lynn, Wallet Prototyping

scopecontent.p: This interactive exercise is designed to give participants the experience of identifying opportunities, understanding customer point of view, rapid prototyping, and giving a pitch. In this exercise, participants interview one another about what they like/hate about their wallets. Based upon what they learn, they build new wallets for their customer.

did.unittitle: Roberts, Janice, Globalization: Acting to be Global

scopecontent.p: Mayfield Fund, a venture capital firm based in Silicon Valley, expands its operations in China and India to ly participate in the companies it funds. Roberts notes that this enables Mayfield Fund to understand the unique opportunities offered by different geographic locations.

did.unittitle: Roberts, Janice, Understanding the 21st Century Consumer

scopecontent.p: Roberts believes that with increasing use of the internet, television and mobile phones, the consumer is moving from early adoption to mainstream consumption. The customer has high expectations of new products and wants to influence technology. Venture capitalists choose to invest in companies that embrace the trends of new and younger consumers.

did.unittitle: Roberts, Janice, Losing Control to the Consumer

scopecontent.p: With consumer participation through user-generated content, blogs, real time feedback, self-promotion and web-based access, Roberts points out that a new form of marketing, viral marketing, is emerging. Viral marketing reflects a shift in power from traditional manufacturers to consumers who can now control the brand image of the product and troubleshoot on their own.

did.unittitle: Roberts, Janice, Economics of Free: A New Business Model

dao.title: Economics of Free: A New Business Model

daodesc.p: Economics of Free: A New Business Model

scopecontent.p: The latest business model for web-based companies is to provide services to the consumers for free. Roberts talks about the operations of such a model, in which advertising is the only source of revenue. She elaborates on how companies are learning to value the concept of 'nothing'.

did.unittitle: Roberts, Janice, Investment Timing: Early, Late or In-between

dao.title: Investment Timing: Early, Late or In-between

daodesc.p: Investment Timing: Early, Late or In-between

scopecontent.p: For a venture capital firm, the time they choose to invest in a company is important. At Mayfield Fund, Roberts explains, they either like to come in early and get a reasonable ownership of the company or take the less risky path of entering at a later stage. However, it is hard to invest in a middle stage deal where money requirements are higher and the concept has not yet been proven.

did.unittitle: Tzuo, Tien, Strategy for Creating Customer Awareness

scopecontent.p: Tzuo, Tien, Chief Strategy Officer for Salesforce.com, believes that investments are shifting from direct-marketing campaigns to online marketing. Customer awareness is created through buzz, PR and dialogues in the marketplace rather than spending a great deal on advertising.

did.unittitle: Tzuo, Tien, Free Trial Product Model

scopecontent.p: With increasingly demanding 21st century customers, Tzuo believes that it is important to provide them with a free trial of the product. This implies that one has to serve the customers even before they have committed, despite resistance from the sales representatives.

did.unittitle: Tzuo, Tien, Contemporary Design for Complex Products

scopecontent.p: Tzuo talks about a methodology used for designing complex products. It involves creating a layered application with dummy samples. The first layer is intuitive and simple. As the layers are peeled, functionality and complexity increase. The customers can choose the degree to which they remove the peels.

did.unittitle: Tzuo, Tien, Sales Model for the Enterprise Software Industry

dao.title: Sales Model for the Enterprise Software Industry

daodesc.p: Sales Model for the Enterprise Software Industry

scopecontent.p: In the enterprise software industry, Tzuo talks about how there has been a shift from the "field-sales" model, where traditional sales representatives win deals from big customers, to a "two-tier-sales" model. This is fueled by customers coming to the website rather than the sales representatives approaching them, creating a need for another tier of sales people to serve as telesales representatives.

did.unittitle: Tzuo, Tien, Importance of Events in the Software Industry

dao.title: Importance of Events in the Software Industry

daodesc.p: Importance of Events in the Software Industry

scopecontent.p: Tzuo talks about how despite the importance of traditional events diminishing with the creation of an online experience, there is still a human factor involved in the customer's decision-making process. They want to see the product, interact with sales reps and talk to other customers. Creating this experience is important for any software company, he adds.

did.unittitle: Tzuo, Tien, Focusing on Post Sales Experience

scopecontent.p: Tzuo explains that with a free trial product model, a high percentage of customers don't end up buying the product. However, it is still important to provide post sales service. A good point of sustainability is when customers have been using the product for some time and it is difficult to unplug them from it, he says.

did.unittitle: Tzuo, Tien, Metrics Driven Sales Model

scopecontent.p: Tzuo believes that as a company grows in revenue and complexity, it is important to have a metrics driven sales model. Factors such as the number of people visiting the company's website, effectiveness of search engine marketing, qualification rates, close rates and average size of deals are all important metrics which help in building a baseline. Tweaking these metrics can improve results and lead to a deeper understanding of the market, he adds.

did.unittitle: Tzuo, Tien, Facing Competition: Creating a Barrier to Entry

dao.title: Facing Competition: Creating a Barrier to Entry

daodesc.p: Facing Competition: Creating a Barrier to Entry

scopecontent.p: In the internet business, the threat from competitors for small and mid-sized organizations is very high, says Tzuo. For this reason, companies like Salesforce.com define the battlefield by not competing with big names. Instead, they cooperate with them to build barriers to entry by investing in technology. Acquiring the right talent from the industry further strengthens these barriers, he adds.

did.unittitle: Bloom, Ron, How to Find the Right Venture Capitalist

dao.title: How to Find the Right Venture Capitalist

daodesc.p: How to Find the Right Venture Capitalist

scopecontent.p: VC Ray Lane talks about why he chose to invest in Bloom's company stressing his belief in Bloom's vision for the podcasting industry. For Bloom, it was about finding a VC who knew what was going on in the industry and could be counted on to make the right decisions not only as an investor but also as a mentor.

did.unittitle: Bloom, Ron, Relationship Between an Entrepreneur and a VC

dao.title: Relationship Between an Entrepreneur and a VC

daodesc.p: Relationship Between an Entrepreneur and a VC

scopecontent.p: Ray Lane, VC for Bloom's company, PodShow, talks about how his commitment as an investor goes beyond investing. He has helped PodShow grow in the market by building connections with the right people. He also believes that conflicts of interest between a VC and founder are mitigated as long as the VC's don't invest in competitors of the company.

did.unittitle: Bloom, Ron, Attracting High Quality Business Opportunities

scopecontent.p: Bloom describes how he has been able to magnetize his company, Podshow, to advertisers by allowing only global brands, to the audience by allowing user-generated content, to producers by allowing the top level producers to make most money, and finally to the engineers by providing them with the right leadership. He also talks about the importance of user generated content, especially for advertisements.

did.unittitle: Bloom, Ron, Influence of Leadership Style on a Company

dao.title: Influence of Leadership Style on a Company

daodesc.p: Influence of Leadership Style on a Company

scopecontent.p: Bloom talks about the importance of leadership in shaping the perception of a company. It is the leader who defines the vision of the company. At PodShow, Bloom and Adam Curry make calculated decisions about the steps they take that are visible to the world. This ensures creation of an image aligned with their vision for the company.

did.unittitle: Bloom, Ron, How to Choose Good Board Members

dao.title: How to Choose Good Board Members

daodesc.p: How to Choose Good Board Members

scopecontent.p: Bloom talks about his relationship with the board of Podshow as an ongoing dynamic one. They spend a lot of time with each other discussing issues as a healthy debate. A good board is one who is able to give advice at the right time and help in making connections. He also believes that the camaraderie of the board with each other is important.

did.unittitle: Hoffman, Reid, Entrepreneurship: A High-risk Investment

scopecontent.p: Hoffman believes that out of three kinds of investment strategies, sure bets, low-risk management and high risk investments, entrepreneurship is the third kind. This style of investment is called accurate contrarian theories where raising sufficient money might help in mitigating risks, but does not ensure success.

did.unittitle: Hoffman, Reid, Fundamental Principles of Entrepreneurship

scopecontent.p: According to Hoffman, working as if you will succeed, getting to failure points and measuring them as early as possible, making a timely entry and exit into the market, taking controlled risks and finally, solving the easiest problems and not the most complex ones are some of the most fundamental principles of entrepreneurship.

did.unittitle: Hoffman, Reid, 3 Key Lessons for an Entrepreneurial Internet Company

dao.title: 3 Key Lessons for an Entrepreneurial Internet Company

daodesc.p: 3 Key Lessons for an Entrepreneurial Internet Company

scopecontent.p: Hoffman describes 3 key lessons he learned at his first company, SocialNet. 1) Financing strategy should reflect one's financial capabilities. 2) Focusing on distribution is important. 3) Understanding that the entrepreneurial skill set is different from what is required to work for an established big company.

did.unittitle: Hoffman, Reid, Facing Competition through Innovation

scopecontent.p: Hoffman believes an entrepreneurial venture will face competition by either innovating against no competitors or against slow competitors.
